Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Boundary Waters–Canadian Derecho was an international derecho that occurred during the afternoon and evening hours of July 4 and the early morning hours of July 5, 1999. It traveled 1,300 miles (2,092 km) and lasted 22 hours. A derecho is a widespread, long-lived, straight-line wind storm that is associated with a fast-moving band of thunderstorms. By definition, if the wind damage swath extends more than 240 miles (about 400 kilometers) and includes wind gusts of at least 58 mph (93 km/h) or greater along most of its length, then the event may be classified as a derecho.
Time_with_Annotation: The Boundary Waters–Canadian Derecho (also called the Boundary Waters Blowdown) was an international derecho that occurred during the afternoon and evening hours of July 4 and the early morning hours of July 5, 1999.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: The Boundary Waters–Canadian Derecho (also called the Boundary Waters Blowdown) was an international derecho that occurred during the afternoon and evening hours of July 4 and the early morning hours of July 5, 1999. It traveled 1,300 miles (2,092 km) and lasted 22 hours.[1]... In the pre-dawn hours of July 4, a band of thunderstorms developed over far eastern North Dakota. Hector International Airport in northwest Fargo recorded winds in excess of 58 mph (95 km/h) for 40 minutes and a maximum wind gust of 91 mph (146 km/h). Many planes were damaged or overturned. The hangars suffered damage as well.... The worst damage occurred farther south in West Fargo, North Dakota and in south central Fargo, North Dakota.  Wind gusts in these areas were estimated at as high as 110 mph (180 km/h).... The derecho moved into Minnesota and caused massive damage in Cass, Itasca, and Aitkin Counties, at around $3 million.... The storm continued southeast and caused more damage in New Hampshire and Vermont, killing one more person, before finally dissipating in Maine after 5:00 a.m. on July 5.

The Boundary Waters–Canadian Derecho (also called the Boundary Waters Blowdown) was an international derecho that occurred during the afternoon and evening hours of July 4 and the early morning hours of July 5, 1999. It traveled 1,300 miles (2,092 km) and lasted 22 hours.[1]... The derecho brought more damage when it crossed the border into Ontario during the early afternoon hours of July 4.... As it raced eastward at 62 mph (100 km/h), the system entered into western Quebec in the Témiscamingue region around 11:00 p.m.... After narrowly missing the Ottawa area, the storm moved quickly into Montreal (M on the map) around 3:00 a.m. heading southeastward toward Maine.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The Boundary Waters–Canadian Derecho (also called the Boundary Waters Blowdown)... It caused 4 fatalities.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In North Dakota, the storm caused $85 million in damage... One person was killed and 60 were injured... In Minnesota, one person was killed and 60 were injured as the derecho passed through the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness... People were there to enjoy canoeing and other recreation for the Independence Day weekend.
Another person in this derecho was killed at Val-des-Lacs when a tree fell on the victim.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The Boundary Waters – Canadian Derecho caused well over $100 million in damage, killed 4 persons and injured 70.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Humberto (2019) was a large and powerful tropical cyclone that caused extensive wind damage in Bermuda during September 2019. It was the eighth named storm, third hurricane, and second major hurricane – Category 3 or higher on the Saffir–Simpson scale – of the 2019 Atlantic hurricane season.
Time_with_Annotation: Hurricane Humberto (2019) formed on September 13, 2019... Dissipated: September 20, 2019

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 2 total

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: St. Johns County, Florida; Duval County, Florida; Topsail Beach, North Carolina
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: One rip current victim in the county was found dead after a two-day search, while another was hospitalized in critical condition... In Topsail Beach, North Carolina, a 62-year-old man drowned after wading into shallow water and getting caught in a rip current.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Hurricane Humberto wrought over $25 million in damage throughout Bermuda.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: A tropical wave moved off the coast of Africa on September 10, with evidence of a low-level circulation and convective banding. It moved west-northwestward, located south of a subtropical ridge. Based on satellite imagery, it is estimated the system organized into Tropical Depression Nine by 1200 UTC on September 11 to the south of the Cape Verde islands... Following the development of a warm spot near the center, Gert intensified into a hurricane on September 13... Gert attained major hurricane strength, or a Category 3 on the Saffir-Simpson scale... Gert strengthened further to peak winds of 150 mph (240 km/h) early on September 16... After nearly all of the convection had dissipated, the system no longer met the characteristics of a tropical cyclone... Gert was the fourth of five Category 4 hurricanes to form during the 1999 season.
Time_with_Annotation: A tropical wave moved off the coast of Africa on September 10, with evidence of a low-level circulation and convective banding... Based on satellite imagery, it is estimated the system organized into Tropical Depression Nine by 1200 UTC on September 11... Hurricane Gert was the fourth of five major hurricanes in the moderately active 1999 Atlantic hurricane season. A Cape Verde hurricane, Gert formed on September 11 off the coast of Africa... Hurricane Gert passed east of Bermuda on September 21... on September 23, Gert transitioned into an extratropical cyclone to the southeast of Atlantic Canada before being absorbed by a larger storm.

Country_with_Annotation.Bermuda: For several days, Gert threatened to strike Bermuda, prompting the evacuation of tourists. Although Gert's center did not make landfall, it passed a short distance east of the island, producing hurricane-force winds that left 11,000 people without power.
Country_with_Annotation.Maine: On September 20, Hurricane Gert was attributed to generating a rogue wave that swept two people out to sea at Acadia National Park along the coast of Maine.
Country_with_Annotation.Atlantic Canada: Late in its duration, Gert passed just southeast of Newfoundland before becoming extratropical, producing wave heights of 77.4 ft (23.6 m) offshore and 30 ft (9 m) onshore. In St. Bride's along the Avalon Peninsula, a large wave severely damaged a wharf, destroying five boats and damaging 45 others.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Fatalities: 2 direct" (this is an exact number mentioned in the article)

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "Although Gert's center did not make landfall, it passed a short distance east of the island, producing hurricane-force winds that left 11,000 people without power. However, the storm's worst effects remained offshore." (this implies no direct deaths in Bermuda)

"On September 20, Hurricane Gert was attributed to generating a rogue wave that swept two people out to sea at Acadia National Park along the coast of Maine. The crew of a lobster boat later found their bodies." (this directly mentions two indirect deaths in the United States due to Gert)
"Along the wharf, a wave swept three people into the ocean, hospitalizing one of them." (this implies one direct death in Canada due to Gert)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Gladys was the farthest tropical cyclone from the United States to be observed by radar in the Atlantic basin since Hurricane Carla in 1961. The seventh named storm and fifth hurricane of the 1975 Atlantic hurricane season, Gladys developed from a tropical wave while several hundred miles southwest of Cape Verde on September 22. Initially, the tropical depression failed to strengthen significantly, but due to warm sea surface temperatures and low wind shear, it became Tropical Storm Gladys by September 24. Despite entering a more unfavorable environment several hundred miles east of the northern Leeward Islands, Gladys became a Category 1 hurricane on the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale on September 28. Shortly thereafter, the storm reentered an area favorable for strengthening. Eventually, a well-defined eye became visible on satellite imagery.
Time_with_Annotation: Hurricane Gladys (1975) was formed: September 22, 1975; Extratropical: October 3; Dissipated: October 4, 1975

Country_with_Annotation.Eastern United States: Effects from the system along the East Coast of the United States were minimal, although heavy rainfall and rough seas were reported.
Country_with_Annotation.Newfoundland and Labrador: Light rainfall was observed, including 1.46 in (37 mm) of precipitation in St. John’s. Strong winds were also reported on the island.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: None

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: There is no specific information about the total economic loss or damage caused by Hurricane Gladys (1975) in the text.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Intense Tropical Cyclone Berguitta was a strong tropical cyclone that caused flooding in Mauritius and Réunion in January 2018. The third tropical system and first intense tropical cyclone of the 2017–18 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season, Berguitta originated from an area of scattered thunderstorms southwest of the Chagos Archipelago on 10 January. It slowly organized as it moved southwards, and became a tropical storm as it turned west on 13 January. Berguitta then rapidly intensified to achieve its peak intensity on 15 January while stalling north of Rodrigues. At the time, the cyclone possessed 10-minute sustained winds of 165 km/h (105 mph), 1-minute sustained winds of 195 km/h (120 mph), and a minimum central pressure of 960 hPa (28.35 inHg). Berguitta weakened as it moved slowly west-southwestwards on 16 January, and the cyclone degraded to a tropical storm by 17 January. It accelerated southwestwards over Mauritius and Réunion on 18 January, before degenerating to a post-tropical cyclone the next day. The remnants of Berguitta transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and dissipated over the Indian Ocean on 24 January.
Time_with_Annotation: A zone of disturbed weather formed within the monsoon trough southwest of the Chagos Archipelago on 10 January. [...] The remnants of Berguitta transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and dissipated over the Indian Ocean on 24 January.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: Intense Tropical Cyclone Berguitta was a strong tropical cyclone that caused flooding in Mauritius and Réunion in January 2018.
Intense Tropical Cyclone Berguitta was a strong tropical cyclone that caused flooding in Mauritius and Réunion in January 2018.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Two fatalities occurred in Mauritius due to Berguitta: a woman died in a road traffic accident on 17 January when her husband lost control of their car, and a man died on 23 January after suffering a head injury on 17 January when falling off a ladder. One person in L'Étang-Salé went missing after being swept away by floodwaters.

One person in L'Étang-Salé went missing after being swept away by floodwaters.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Overall economic losses across the island were estimated at €41 million (US$48 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Lili was a tropical storm that affected the Lesser Antilles, Haiti, Jamaica, Cuba, the Yucatán Peninsula, Cayman Islands, Louisiana, and other areas in the United States. This is evident in the original text which states, 'Hurricane Lili was the second costliest, deadliest, and strongest hurricane of the 2002 Atlantic hurricane season, only surpassed by Hurricane Isidore, which affected the same areas around a week before Lili. Lili was the twelfth named storm, fourth hurricane, and second major hurricane of the 2002 Atlantic hurricane season.' Furthermore, the text mentions that 'The system turned to the northwest and sped up, becoming a major hurricane on October 2 while 365 miles (587 km) south-southeast of New Orleans' and 'The system reached its peak strength of category 4 intensity, with winds of 145 mph (233 km/h), during that afternoon.' These statements confirm that Hurricane Lili was a tropical storm/cyclone.
Time_with_Annotation:
Formed: September 21, 2002
Dissipated: October 4, 2002

Country_with_Annotation.St. Lucia: "St. Lucia lost at least 75 percent of its banana crop, and hundreds of homes were damaged by the strong winds. Near total loss of electricity, water, and telephone services occurred, and utility systems were heavily damaged. Four people were killed on the island, and total damage was estimated at $20 million (2002 USD)"
Country_with_Annotation.Barbados: "Over 400 homes were damaged in Barbados, and nearly 50 trees were downed by the high gusts. Similar to in St. Lucia, there was significant damage to the nation's banana crop. Extensive loss of electricity and telephone service also occurred. Damage totaled at nearly $200,000 (2002 USD)."
Country_with_Annotation.Grenada: "A total of 14 homes' roofs were damaged, and one was completely destroyed. The island Medical Centre's roof was also damaged, and 12 landslides were reported. There was also mild damage to infrastructure, particularly in St. Patrick's Parish; three bridges were damaged or destroyed, along with seven utility poles and a water main. The entire island was without power at some point, but it was quickly restored in the southern part of the island where damage to the poles themselves was less significant."
Country_with_Annotation.St. Vincent and the Grenadines: "Several hundred homes and two schools were damaged, and the Rose Hall Police Station's roof was lost. Still, the majority of damage was dealt to the agricultural industry. In all, damage to the islands totaled $40 million (2002 USD)."
Country_with_Annotation.Haiti: "The storm's major impact was extremely heavy rainfall, in excess of 16 inches (410 mm) near the settlement of Camp-Perrin, Haiti. This caused the Ravine du Sud River to overflow, and submerge buildings in the town. Two people died in the mudslides these rains triggered, and two more drowned in the flooding around Camp-Perrin. The floods also seriously damaged crops and infrastructure; over 1700 homes were damaged and 240 were destroyed."
Country_with_Annotation.Jamaica: "Extremely heavy rainfall inundated the island. Cedar Valley recorded the most rainfall, with 23.1 inches (590 mm) measured. This led to prolific flooding that triggered mudslides across the island and killed four people. These floods decimated the island's sugar cane crop, one of the island's principal exports."
Country_with_Annotation.Cuba: "Lili made landfall as a category two hurricane twice in Cuba, on the Isle of Youth and in the Pinar del Río Province, on October 1. Wind gusts up to 112 mph (180 km/h) and rainfall amounts reaching 6 inches (150 mm) in some places caused damage to homes, businesses and crops. One person was killed."
Country_with_Annotation.Louisiana: "Lili made landfall on the morning of October 3 near Intracoastal City, as a weakening category one hurricane. Wind gusts reaching 120 mph (190 km/h), coupled with over 6 inches (150 mm) of rainfall and a storm surge of 12 feet (3.7 m) caused over $790 million (2002 USD) in damage to Louisiana. A total of 237,000 people lost power, and oil rigs offshore were shut down for up to a week. Crops were badly affected, particularly the sugar cane, damage totaled nearly $175 million (2002 USD). No direct deaths were reported as early warnings and the compact nature of the storm circumvented major loss of life."
Country_with_Annotation.Mississippi: "Lili's outer rainbands dumped large amounts of rain and brought tropical storm force wind gusts to Mississippi. Minor power outages occurred, mainly in southern Mississippi, and combined with the flooding of roads and buildings caused $30 million (2002 USD) in damage. No deaths occurred in Mississippi."
Country_with_Annotation.Arkansas: "Hurricane Lili's remnants brought heavy rainfall, peaking at four inches in Arkansas, to the Southeast, before dissipating near the Arkansas-Tennessee border."
Country_with_Annotation.Tennessee: "Hurricane Lili's remnants also caused minimal rainfall in the Lower Tennessee Valley. No major damage was reported."

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: A total of 15 people died in the Caribbean Islands, and 2 more were killed in the United States.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: St. Lucia, Barbados, Grenada, St. Vincent and the Grenadines
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Lili affected the islands as a tropical storm... Winds in the area were generally below hurricane force, although some gusts exceeded 74 mph (119 km/h)... The winds, combined with poor construction, tore the roofs off numerous homes and businesses... The majority of the damage was dealt to primarily to the banana crop... St. Lucia lost at least 75% of its banana crop, and hundreds of homes were damaged by the strong winds... Over 400 homes were damaged in Barbados, and nearly 50 trees were downed by the high gusts... Grenada also experienced moderate damage... St. Vincent and the Grenadines were heavily damaged, especially compared to other islands in the area.

Lili made landfall on the morning of October 3 near Intracoastal City, as a weakening category one hurricane... Wind gusts reaching 120 mph (190 km/h), coupled with over 6 inches (150 mm) of rainfall and a storm surge of 12 feet (3.7 m) caused over $790 million (2002 USD) in damage to Louisiana... No direct deaths were reported as early warnings and the compact nature of the storm circumvented major loss of life.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Alby was first identified on 27 March 1978 as a disorganized area of low pressure situated roughly 800 km (500 mi) north-northwest of Karratha... The system was characterized as a large cluster of convection converging around the low... Early on 29 March, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC), classified the system as a tropical storm... Shortly thereafter, the Bureau of Meteorology in Perth classified it as a tropical cyclone, assigning it with the name Alby... By then, a large ragged eye developed and Alby steadily intensified through 2 April... At the end of this strengthening, Cyclone Alby attained its peak intensity as a Category 5 on the Australian cyclone intensity scale... Additionally, the JTWC assessed the storm to have attained winds of 215 km/h (134 mph), a low-range Category 4 on the Saffir–Simpson hurricane scale.
Time_with_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Alby was first identified on 27 March 1978... The storm brushed the cape on 4 April, bringing hurricane-force winds, before rapidly losing its identity the following day.

Country_with_Annotation.Western Australia: The combination of Alby's fast movement and hurricane-force winds caused widespread damage in Western Australia. Along the coast, large swells flooded low-lying areas and numerous homes lost their roofs from high winds. Further inland, bushfires were worsened by the storm as it brought little rain, generally less than 20 mm (0.79 in) along the coast. These fires burned roughly 114,000 hectares (281,700 acres) and destroyed two towns.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Along the coast, large swells produced by the storm resulted in two fatalities in Albany Harbour as well as significant coastal damage... One person died in Toodyay after falling off his roof while trying to repair it... Two people were killed while trying to suppress the fires: one from a fallen tree in Mount Barker and the other in Manjiump when a bulldozer clearing a firebreak flipped over.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Along the coast, large swells produced by the storm resulted in two fatalities in Albany Harbour as well as significant coastal damage.
One person died in Toodyay after falling off his roof while trying to repair it.
Two people were killed while trying to suppress the fires: one from a fallen tree in Mount Barker and the other in Manjiump when a bulldozer clearing a firebreak flipped over.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The resulting damage was extensive, with monetary losses reaching A$50 million (US$45 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Kirk originated from a tropical wave that left Africa on September 20 and organized into a tropical depression two days later. The system intensified into Tropical Storm Kirk early on September 22 but quickly degenerated into a tropical wave again early the next day. A reduction in the disturbance's forward speed allowed it to regain tropical storm intensity on September 26. Kirk reached maximum sustained winds of 65 mph (100 km/h) that morning before increasing westerly wind shear caused the cyclone to steadily weaken. The storm made landfall on Saint Lucia with winds of 50 mph (80 km/h) before continuing into the Caribbean Sea. Kirk degenerated to a tropical wave again on September 28, and its remnants continued westward, contributing to the formation of Hurricane Michael ten days later.

Country_with_Annotation.Barbados: Kirk produced sustained winds of 40 mph (64 km/h), gusting to 46 mph (74 km/h), on Barbados as it passed within 40 miles (64 km) of the island.[1]
Country_with_Annotation.Windward Islands: Heavy rainfall and resultant river flooding also affected northeastern Saint Vincent, with precipitation totals exceeding 4 in (100 mm). Coastal flooding due to high surf forced three families to evacuate their homes in New Sandy Bay Village and seek shelter in a public school.[11][26]
Country_with_Annotation.Guadeloupe: Guadeloupe experienced lighter winds but more significant rainfall than Martinique, with precipitation totals reaching 6.81 in (173 mm) at Petit-Bourg.[41]
Country_with_Annotation.Martinique: Gusty winds extended northward to Martinique; weather stations at standard 33-foot (10 m) elevation recorded sustained winds of 41 mph (66 km/h), gusting to 58 mph (93 km/h). One station at higher elevation observed a peak gust to 69 mph (111 km/h).[1]
Country_with_Annotation.Jamaica: After Kirk dissipated, its remnants interacted with a trough of low pressure to produce showers and thunderstorms across Jamaica that prompted the dissemination of flash flood watches.[42]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 1998 Gujarat cyclone, also known as Tropical Cyclone 03A, was a catastrophic tropical cyclone that killed at least 1,000 people in India, mainly in the state of Gujarat. It developed as an area of low pressure over the Laccadive Islands on June 1 and intensified into a cyclonic storm by June 4. The storm moved slowly towards the west and weakened as wind shear increased, but it redeveloped and regained strength as it turned towards the north. The storm neared the Indian coastline, developed an eye, and strengthened into the equivalent of a major hurricane with winds reaching 185 km/h (115 mph). It made landfall near Porbandar in the Indian state of Gujarat between 01:00 and 02:00 UTC on June 9 with winds of 195 km/h (120 mph). The IMD assessed the storm to be a very severe cyclonic storm at this time, with winds up to 165 km/h (105 mph) and a barometric pressure of 958 hPa (mbar). After landfall, the JTWC issued their final advisory and the IMD continued to monitor ARB 02 until it weakened to a depression on June 10.
Time_with_Annotation: On June 1, an area of low pressure developed over the Laccadive Islands. Two days later, the JTWC issued a TCFA for the system as it became better organized. Early on June 4, the JTWC issued its first advisory on Tropical Cyclone 03A. Around the same time, the IMD began monitoring the system as Depression ARB 02. Shortly after, the depression was upgraded to a deep depression and further strengthened into a cyclonic storm the following day. The small storm moved slowly towards the west and weakened as wind shear began to increase. The storm weakened below tropical storm intensity later that day and the initial final advisory was issued. However, the system redeveloped and advisories resumed the next day. The storm gradually intensified as it moved towards the northwest. The IMD assessed the storm to be a very severe cyclonic storm at this time, with winds up to 165 km/h (105 mph) and a barometric pressure of 958 hPa (mbar). After slightly weakening early on June 9, 03A re-strengthened, attaining its peak intensity with winds of 195 km/h (120 mph). Then it made landfall near Porbandar in the Indian state of Gujarat between 01:00 and 02:00 UTC on June 9. The storm weakened following landfall and the JTWC issued their final advisory later that day. The IMD continued to monitor ARB 02 until June 10, by which time it had weakened to a depression before dissipating.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The 1998 Gujarat cyclone (Joint Typhoon Warning Center designation: 03A; India Meteorological Department designation: ARB 02) was a catastrophic tropical cyclone that killed at least 1,000 people in India, mainly in the state of Gujarat. ... Tropical Cyclone 03A brought a large storm surge of 4.9 m (16 ft) which devastated coastal communities and salt mines. An estimated 4,000 to 10,000 people were killed by the storm, many of whom were salt mine workers who did not own a radio and received little or no warning of the cyclone. The large loss of life was partially attributed to contractors who wanted to continue making profits and did not inform their workers of the approaching storm. According to the official figures, 1173 people died and 1774 people went missing. ... At least 893 people were injured by the storm and over 11,000 animals were killed. Over 162,000 structures were damaged or destroyed throughout the affected area and damages amounted to Rs. 120 billion (US$3 billion). In Kandla, the damages were estimated around ₹1,855.33 crore (equivalent to ₹84 billion or US$1.0 billion in 2023).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Storm Kelly, known in the Philippines as Tropical Storm Daling, was a weak but destructive tropical storm that struck the Philippines in June 1981. The system was first detected by weather satellite imagery on June 25 and classified as a tropical depression on June 30 by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC). It moved westward, reaching tropical storm status before hitting the central Philippines. Kelly weakened over the islands but re-strengthened over the South China Sea, nearly attaining typhoon status on July 2. The cyclone passed through the southern Hainan Island on July 3 and crossed the Gulf of Tonkin as a weakening tropical storm, making landfall in northern Vietnam on July 4 as a tropical storm. Kelly dissipated two days later inland.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: A tropical disturbance organized into a tropical depression east of the Philippines on June 28. It tracked westward, reaching tropical storm on June 30 before hitting the central Philippines.
The cyclone then crossed the Gulf of Tonkin as a weakening tropical storm, and made landfall in northern Vietnam on July 4 as a tropical storm. Kelly dissipated two days later inland.
The cyclone then crossed the Gulf of Tonkin as a weakening tropical storm, and made landfall in northern Vietnam on July 4 as a tropical storm. Kelly dissipated two days later inland.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Storm Alex was a powerful early-season extratropical cyclone that made landfall in Brittany on 1 October. Originally, it was a minor low-pressure system to the south west of Greenland late on 27 September and tracked south eastwards, experiencing the Fujiwhara effect and then undergoing explosive cyclogenesis.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation:
The insurance and reinsurance industry loss caused by extratropical cyclone, or European windstorm, Friederike (David), which struck northern Europe in January, has been pegged at EUR 1.465 billion (approximately US $1.8 billion) by PERILS AG.
Windstorm Friederike caused significant damage as it tracked across European countries including the British Isles, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany on 17th and 18th January 2018.
PERILS, which has completed its initial assessment of Friederike’s impact on insurance and reinsurance interests, said that the extratropical cyclone windstorm was compact and fast-moving, generating particularly strong winds in the Netherlands and Germany, where a record gust of 203km/h was registered on the Brocken mountain in the state of Saxony-Anhalt.

Hurricane Gustav (/ˈɡʊstɑːv/) was the second most destructive hurricane of the 2008 Atlantic hurricane season. The seventh tropical cyclone, third hurricane, and second major hurricane of the season, Gustav caused serious damage and casualties in Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, Cuba and the United States. Gustav caused at least $8.31 billion (2008 USD) in damages.[1]

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Hurricane Gustav caused at least 153 deaths in the U.S. and Caribbean. Damage in the U.S. totaled to $6 billion (2008 USD) with additional damage of $2.1 billion in Cuba and $210 million in damage in Jamaica.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Hurricane made landfall near the town of Jacmel
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: According to Haiti's National Director of Civil Protection, 77 people died as a result of the hurricane. Some 2,100 houses were destroyed and another 8,150 damaged, causing an estimated 7,200 people to live in temporary shelters, including churches, community centers and schools.

In the Dominican Republic, a landslide in a rural area killed eight people. Two people were injured. Government authorities said that some 67,255 persons were evacuated and more than 1,239 homes were damaged with 12 destroyed. 50 communities were isolated by the flooding.

In Jamaica, 15 deaths were reported after Gustav swept through the area as a tropical storm. Flash flooding was also reported on the island as a result of Gustav's heavy rains. The banana sector in the parishes of St. Thomas, St. Mary and Portland suffered significant damage. The Hope River Bridge linking the capital Kingston with the eastern reaches of the city including Harbour View and St. Thomas collapsed and the Georgia bridge in Portland was destroyed. Jamaica's government ministry initially estimated US$41.8 million in damage to the road infrastructure in the country. Total damage in Jamaica was estimated at $210 million.

In the Cayman Islands, Gustav's heavy rains and storm surge flooded the streets of Cayman Brac and Little Cayman, the smaller easternmost 'Sister Islands' in the chain. More than 1,100 people spent the night in government shelters in the three islands as high waves and heavy winds battered the chain.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Isla de la Juventud, Pinar del Río, and Los Palacios
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: At least 300,000 people were evacuated from Gustav's path as 155 mph (249 km/h) winds toppled telephone poles and fruit trees, shattered windows and tore off the tin roofs of homes. Cuban authorities declared that Gustav is the worst hurricane to hit the country in 50 years. Authorities called the storm damage the worst since 1956. The 211 mph (340 km/h) wind gusts registered in the city of Paso Real de San Diego were the highest in Cuba's history, according to the provincial newspaper, the Guerrillero. Winds were so strong that the weather station instruments broke. Gustav is considered Cuba's worst hurricane in 45 years, the last hurricane that was worse than Gustav for Cuba was Hurricane Flora in 1963, which was the deadliest Cuban storm since the 1932 Cuba Hurricane. Cuban Civil defense authorities initially stated that there were 'many people injured' on Isla de la Juventud, an island of 87,000 people south of the mainland. Nearly all the island's roads were washed out and some regions were heavily flooded. No fatalities have been reported in Cuba, despite the extreme damage.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia, and Arkansas
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Forty-eight deaths in the state of Louisiana were blamed on Hurricane Gustav. Two people from Metairie, Louisiana died near Vicksburg in an automobile accident while evacuating from the storm. In Mississippi, damage from Gustav was far less severe than that caused by Hurricane Katrina, with its 2005 storm surge of 27 ft (8.2 m); however, Gustav's storm surge was high as 15 feet (4.6 m) in places on the Mississippi Gulf Coast. Sections of U.S. Route 90 (including Gulfport and Biloxi) were flooded and some houses were flooded. Two people from Metairie, Louisiana died near Vicksburg in an automobile accident while evacuating from the storm. In Alabama, scattered damage already reached multimillion-dollar levels, with the destruction of the Dauphin Island berm (sand dune barrier) by storm surge waves, flood damage to island roads & homes, and extensive flooding around Bayou La Batre. The manmade sand berm took about two years to complete, and construction of another berm for Dauphin Island started in 2010, which acts as a barrier island for the western Alabama coastline at Mobile Bay. Four people died in rip currents on Florida beaches. Four people died in a car accident on Interstate 20 near Carrollton, Georgia while evacuating from Louisiana. Two other people in the car were alive and airlifted to nearby hospitals.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Hurricane Gustav caused at least $8.31 billion (2008 USD) in damages.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Mamie originated from the southwesterly monsoonal flow near the Philippines... At 2300 UTC on August 15, the aircraft discovered a closed low-level circulation, as well as tropical storm-force winds... Based on this, both agencies designated the system as Tropical Storm Mamie early on August 16... On August 16, the tropical storm began to turn northwest... At 0000 UTC on August 17, the JTWC classified Mamie as a typhoon... Around midday, the JTWC estimated winds of 130 km/h (80 mph)... However, the aforementioned ridge was not strong enough to prevent the storm from turning north-northwest on August 17... That evening, the JMA upgraded Mamie to typhoon status... Simultaneously, the JMA estimated peak winds of 120 km/h (75 mph)... According to the JMA, the typhoon held on to peak intensity for 12 hours while moving onshore near Shanghai on August 18... Mamie only gradually weakened overland... Typhoon Mamie moved offshore at 0200 UTC on August 19... Following a turn towards the northwest, Tropical Storm Mamie briefly emerged into the Yellow Sea before making a third and final landfall just west of Dairen at noon.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The system was first monitored by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) at 0600 UTC on August 14; the JTWC noted that the chances of significant development were poor. Throughout the day, the system became better organized while turning north[1] and at 1800 UTC that day, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) started watching the disturbance.[2][nb 1]

At 0000 UTC on August 14, banding features were noted via satellite imagery. The system was first monitored by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) at 0600 UTC on August 14; the JTWC noted that the chances of significant development were poor.[1]

After making landfall, Typhoon Mamie dropped 420 mm (17 in) of rain in Liaoning, where the storm flooded 300,000 ha (741,315 acres) of farmland.[10] Due to a combination of Mamie and previous flooding, 19 rivers overflowed.[11] The typhoon forced 1,000 factories to temporarily close,[12] and toppled about 6.5 million trees.[13] Over 8,000 dwellings were flooded. More than 3,000 residents were evacuated in the Jilin province.[14] At least 36,400 villagers necessitated rescue.[12] Nearly 1 million individuals were directly affected by the typhoon.[15] Elsewhere, in Yantai, the typhoon killed more than 120,000 animals, damaged 120,000 homes, and sank more than 200 boats.[16] Waves up to 8 m (26 ft) in height pounded the Bohai Bay shoreline, forcing more than 200 ships to be evacuated. Cables securing an oil rig were snapped.[10] One person died while trying to fasten steel products on a ship.[6] In all, 17 people perished[17] and 165 were injured due to Mamie.[18] Loses totaled $172 million.[13]

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Overall, 17 fatalities occurred and 165 were injured. Losses totaled $172 million (1985 USD).

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Shortly after making landfall, Mamie was considered the worst storm to affect northeastern China in 26 years. In all, 17 people perished and 165 were injured due to Mamie.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Maria was a Category 1 hurricane that made landfall on the island of Newfoundland during September 2011. Originating from a tropical wave over the central Atlantic on September 6, Maria moved toward the west and slowly strengthened. While approaching the northern Leeward Islands, however, the system entered a region of higher vertical wind shear and cooler sea surface temperatures, causing it to degenerate into a low-pressure area. It slowly curved toward the north and northeast around the western periphery of the subtropical ridge, and regained tropical storm status on September 10. Maria further strengthened to attain hurricane status while making its closest approach to Bermuda. The cyclone attained peak winds of 80 mph (130 km/h) on September 16, but weakened thereafter because of an increase in wind shear and cooler sea surface temperatures. Maria made landfall on the southeastern coast of Newfoundland during the afternoon hours of September 16 before becoming absorbed by a frontal system later on that same day.

Formed: September 6, 2011
Dissipated: September 18, 2011

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Kyle, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Luring, was the first of five deadly tropical cyclones that affected and impacted the Philippines and Vietnam during the 1993 Pacific typhoon season. The twenty-seventh named storm and thirteenth typhoon of the season, Kyle formed from a monsoon depression near Palau, associated with bursts of scattered convection. It then drifted west-northwest, strengthening to a tropical storm the next day. Land interaction prevented further intensification, and it crossed through the central Philippines while maintaining its intensity on November 20. Upon entering the South China Sea, the system strengthened to a severe tropical storm before rapidly intensifying to a typhoon, three days later. It soon reached its peak intensity that day, with one-minute maximum sustained winds of 175 km/h (110 mph), equivalent to a mid-level Category 2 typhoon.

Time_with_Annotation.Start_Date: At 12:00 UTC on November 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center started to monitor a monsoon depression associated with a weak area of convection near Yap State.
Time_with_Annotation.End_Date: The last warning was issued by the JMA and JTWC as Kyle dissipated near the Cambodia-Thailand border on November 24.

Country_with_Annotation.Caroline Islands: The system started to move to the west-northwest while slowly organizing, behind a favorable environment of low wind shear and warm sea surface temperatures near Yap State.
Country_with_Annotation.Palau: The disturbance was associated with bursts of scattered convection near Palau.
Country_with_Annotation.Yap: The disturbance was associated with bursts of scattered convection near Palau.
Country_with_Annotation.Philippines: It then traversed the province before moving through Ormoc Bay, just before another landfall between 09:00 and 10:00 UTC on Merida, Leyte. There, Kyle became highly disorganized while moving through the Visayas, although it remained a tropical storm.
Country_with_Annotation.Vietnam: Officials in Vietnam reported 106 deaths, 59 missing, and 476 injuries due to the typhoon. Torrential downpour and strong winds destroyed 5,601 houses and submerged over 11,217 more. Some schools also collapsed and bridges were washed out due to strong currents from overflowed rivers. Over 17,212 hectares of farmlands were also destroyed and hundreds of fishing boats sustained damages.
Country_with_Annotation.Cambodia: It entered the nearby Cambodia as a tropical depression.
Country_with_Annotation.Thailand: The remnants of the storm also caused floods in Thailand. Some authorities in Nakhon Si Thammarat reported three fatalities, all due to unknown reasons.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Edouard was the strongest hurricane of the 1996 Atlantic hurricane season, reaching winds of 145 mph (230 km/h). Edouard remained a major hurricane for eight days, an unusually long amount of time. A Cape Verde hurricane, the storm formed near the coast of Africa in the middle of August and moved westward then curved northward, persisting until early September when it became extratropical to the southeast of New England. Edouard was originally forecast to strike the northeast United States, but it produced hurricane-force gusts to portions of southeastern Massachusetts while remaining offshore. The winds caused minor damage totaling $20 million.

Country_with_Annotation.Cape Verde: A tropical wave moved off the coast of Africa on August 19, accompanied with spiral bands of convection around an area of low pressure. A large circulation quickly developed once it reached the Atlantic Ocean, and the system organized into Tropical Depression Four late on August 19 while located 345 mi (555 km) southeast of Cape Verde.
Country_with_Annotation.Lessar Antilles: Hurricane Edouard passed about 250 mi (400 km) north of the Lesser Antilles on August 28.
Country_with_Annotation.Bermuda: On September 1, the hurricane passed about midway between Bermuda and Cape Hatteras,
Country_with_Annotation.United States: Edouard produced hurricane-force gusts to portions of southeastern Massachusetts while remaining offshore. The winds caused minor damage totaling $20 million. In addition, the hurricane generated strong waves and rip currents to coastlines, killing two people in Ocean City, New Jersey and causing numerous injuries.
Country_with_Annotation.Canada: The hurricane also caused beach erosion on southeastern Nova Scotia.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In addition, the hurricane generated strong waves and rip currents to coastlines, killing two people in Ocean City, New Jersey and causing numerous injuries.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In New Jersey, strong waves killed two people and seriously injured another. Lifeguards made numerous rescues along the coast, while other beaches were closed or had restrictions on bathing.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The greatest damage occurred on Cape Cod, where moderate wind gusts resulted in $4.6 million (2007 USD).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Dot was a powerful hurricane which affected Hawaii in August 1959, making it, at the time, the costliest tropical cyclone in Hawaiian history. Dot was first identified as a strong tropical storm southeast of Hawaiʻi on August 1. The storm was potentially a continuation of a previously unnamed tropical cyclone that was monitored west of the Baja California Peninsula from July 24–27, but was never confirmed due to a lack of ship reports. Dot was quick to intensify, reaching hurricane intensity six hours after naming. By August 3, Dot reached its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds reaching 150 mph (240 km/h). Intensity leveled off afterwards as Dot tracked westward before making a curve towards the northwest on August 5, after which the hurricane weakened at a faster clip. Dot made landfall the next day on Kauai as a minimal hurricane before dissipating west of the Hawaiian Islands on August 8.
Time_with_Annotation: On July 24, the SS Pacificus encountered a storm with maximum sustained winds meeting the threshold of tropical storm status roughly 1,000 mi (1,600 km) west of the Baja California Peninsula.[1] However, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) discontinued its monitoring of the cyclone on July 27 due to a lack of ship reports confirming the location of the tropical storm.[1]

At 1800 UTC on August 1, an unidentified ship roughly 950 mi (1,550 km) southeast of Hilo, Hawaii reported 70 mph (110 km/h) winds within a storm, prompting the JTWC to initiate advisories on Tropical Storm Dot.[2]
Hurricane Dot (1959) dissipated west of the Hawaiian Islands on August 8.

Country_with_Annotation.Hawaii: Hurricane Dot was a powerful hurricane which affected Hawaii in August 1959, making it, at the time, the costliest tropical cyclone in Hawaiian history. Dot produced heavy rainfall and gusty winds as it passed south of the Big Island, Lanai, Maui, Molokai, and Oahu, resulting in minor damage. In Oahu, some homes along the coast were unroofed, and damage from wave action was also reported. Damage from these four islands totaled US$150,000, and two indirect deaths occurred in Lanai. Extensive damage occurred on Kauai as Dot made landfall, producing wind gusts as high as 103 mph (166 km/h) and toppling trees and power lines. Widespread power outages affected the island, causing telecommunications and water systems to fail. Although infrastructure was damaged to an extent by floodwater and strong winds, crops suffered the most losses. Cane sugar crops sustained US$2.7 million in losses. Overall, damage from Dot across Hawaii totaled US$6 million, and a disaster area declaration and state of emergency took effect for the archipelago after the hurricane's passage.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 2 indirect

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Dot produced heavy rainfall and gusty winds as it passed south of the Big Island, Lanai, Maui, Molokai, and Oahu, resulting in minor damage. ... Damage from these four islands totaled US$150,000, and two indirect deaths occurred in Lanai. ... Despite making landfall as a weak Category 1 hurricane, Dot brought damaging winds inland, with a maximum wind gust of 103 mph (166 km/h) reported at Kilauea Light. However, gusts as high as 125 mph (200 km/h) were estimated given the snapping of palm trees. Strong winds damaged hundreds of buildings in the areas of Kilauea, Lihue, and Lawai, Hawaii. ... The toppling of power lines caused power outages across the island; fallen lines also blocked roads. Water supply to some communities failed due to the lack of electricity. ... With the exception of emergency radio transmitters, telecommunications on Kauai failed. ... Due to the damage wrought by Dot on Kauai, the island was declared a major disaster area. ... The damage toll from Dot for the entirety of Hawaiʻi totaled US$6 million, making the hurricane the costliest in Hawaiian history before it was surpassed by hurricanes Iwa, Iniki and Iselle in 1982, 1992 and 2014, respectively.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Danielle was a strong tropical storm that made landfall on Virginia in the 1992 Atlantic hurricane season. It formed out of a stationary trough of low pressure on September 18 near the coast of North Carolina and developed into Tropical Depression Six later that day. The depression rapidly organized and attained tropical storm status just six hours after forming. Danielle looped to the west due to a change in steering currents and reached a peak of 65 mph (105 km/h) winds before weakening and hitting the Delmarva Peninsula. The storm quickly dissipated over land.
Time_with_Annotation:
Formed: September 22, 1992
Dissipated: September 26, 1992

Country_with_Annotation.North Carolina: Tropical Storm Danielle made landfall on the Eastern Shore of Virginia late on the 25th, producing higher than normal tides and strong waves along the coastline, causing beach erosion and light coastal damage.
Country_with_Annotation.Virginia: Tropical Storm Danielle made landfall on the Eastern Shore of Virginia late on the 25th, producing higher than normal tides and strong waves along the coastline, causing beach erosion and significant overwash, leaving parts of Norfolk under 2 feet (0.61 m) of water.
Country_with_Annotation.Maryland: Upon making landfall Danielle produced an estimated storm tide of 2 to 3 feet (0.61 to 0.91 m) in Ocean City, Maryland. Waves from the storm caused minor to moderate beach erosion along the coastline, and the combination of waves and high tides caused moderate street flooding.
Country_with_Annotation.Delaware: Danielle caused 2 to 3-foot (.6 to .9-m) higher than normal tides, along with strong waves. The combination of the two flooded some coastal houses and resulted in significant beach and dune erosion.
Country_with_Annotation.New Jersey: Strong waves from the storm washed out miles of beaches along the coastline. In Ocean City, the waves passed over the boardwalk and into houses. Further north, the waves crashed a four-person, 35-foot (10-m) sailboat near Island Beach State Park. Two managed to swim safely to shore, though the other two occupants drowned.
Country_with_Annotation.Pennsylvania: Danielle rapidly weakened over land, and dissipated over eastern Pennsylvania on September 26.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The combination of Danielle and a high pressure system produced higher than normal tides and strong waves, causing beach erosion and light coastal damage. The waves killed two in New Jersey from a boat sinking, and also destroyed three houses in the Outer Banks of North Carolina.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The waves washed out miles of beaches along the coastline. In Ocean City, the waves passed over the boardwalk and into houses. Further north, the waves crashed a four-person, 35-foot (10-m) sailboat near Island Beach State Park. Two managed to swim safely to shore, though the other two occupants drowned.
Three other houses in the Outer Banks were threatened by the storm.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Overall damage from the storm was minimal.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Anne (2014) was a European windstorm that caused €75 million in damage across western Europe in early January 2014. The low pressure system was named Anne by the Free University of Berlin on 1 January and deepened by the powerful jet stream, one of a series of lows which deepened below 950hPa. This is capable of adding over half a meter to sea levels. The storm coincided with high spring tides, and high discharge levels in rivers and estuaries. The long fetch of winds over the western Atlantic pushed water against the coasts, and helped to develop some significant wave heights, especially where the coastal morphology acts to funnel the waves.
Time_with_Annotation: The low pressure system was named Anne by the Free University of Berlin on 1 January.[2] ... Cyclone Anne (2014) dissipated on 6 January.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths directly or indirectly caused by Cyclone Anne (2014).

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Cyclone Anne (2014) caused €75 million in damage across western Europe in early January 2014.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Storm Warren, known in the Philippines as Tropical Storm Reming, affected the Philippines during October 1984. An area of convection was first observed on October 17 in the Philippine Sea... At 00:00 UTC on October 23, both the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) and the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) started tracking the system... The aforementioned circulation was at first exposed from the deep convection, but by 03:00 UTC on October 23, the storm had rapidly become better organized... Early on October 24, the JMA classified Warren as a severe tropical storm... On October 26, Warren stalled out for the next 12 hours, only to drift east-northeast in response to the inflow to Typhoon Vanessa and a trough to its north... By October 29, Warren began to expand in size in response to a monsoonal surge of moisture into the South China Sea... At 06:00 UTC on October 29, the JTWC downgraded Warren into a tropical storm... On August 30, the storm exited PASAGA's warning zone... The remnants of the storm later crossed the coast of Vietnam... Late on November 1, the circulation had become less defined and increasingly difficult to locate, and the JTWC estimated that Warren dissipated the next day.
Time_with_Annotation: The precursor of Tropical Storm Warren was first noted on October 17... At 00:00 UTC on October 23, both the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) and the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) started tracking the system... Late on November 1, the circulation had become less defined and increasingly difficult to locate, and the JTWC estimated that Warren dissipated the next day... During the afternoon of November 2, the JMA ceased tracking Warren.

Country_with_Annotation.Philippines: The system developed into a tropical storm on October 23, and was named Warren by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The storm moved north and later north-northwest but late on October 24, the storm began to meander in the South China Sea. On October 26, Warren drifted west while attaining peak strength... Across the island chain, 73 people died, 25 due to landslides, while 18 others were injured...
Country_with_Annotation.Vietnam: Despite this, the storm's center remained well-defined for an additional 24 hours. The remnants of the storm later crossed the coast of Vietnam, with winds of 55 to 65 km/h (35 to 40 mph)... Late on November 1, the circulation had become less defined and increasingly difficult to locate, and the JTWC estimated that Warren dissipated the next day... During the afternoon of November 2, the JMA ceased tracking Warren.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Across the island chain, 73 people died, 25 due to landslides, while 18 others were injured.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Nationwide, 73 people perished, with 18 others hurt.
Elsewhere, twelve other people died due landslides.
In the province of Bataan, 30 houses were destroyed, which led to 200 people without a home.
Twenty-nine people, including two children, drowned due to the incident.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The main event 'Elon-Felix' is categorized as an Extratropical Storm/Cyclone. This is supported by the text: 'European windstorms Elon-Felix affected Western and Northern Europe from 8th to 11th January 2015... the storm is also known as Dagmar-Egon in Denmark and Sweden, and as Nina in Norway.' Further evidence is found in the statement: 'The main characteristics of Elon-Felix were the rapid succession of two low-pressure systems, generating strong winds which affected almost identical areas within 24 hours.' Additionally, a wind-speed value map is provided, showing the maximum wind gust values for the storm.
Time_with_Annotation: Elon-Felix affected Western and Northern Europe from 8th to 11th January 2015 and the storm is also known as Dagmar-Egon in Denmark and Sweden, and as Nina in Norway.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths associated with 'Elon-Felix|Dagmar-Egon|Nina'.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: PERILS’ initial estimate of the insured industry-wide property market loss for Elon-Felix is €328m.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: In mid-January 2022, the Southern Cone had a severe heat wave, which made the region for a while the hottest place on earth, with temperatures exceeding those of the Middle East... Several cities had high temperatures over 40 °C (104 °F), setting records for hot days... In addition, thousands of hectares were destroyed by wildfires across the region.
Time_with_Annotation: This extreme weather event was associated with the Atlantic anticyclone, a particularly intense La Niña phenomenon in the Pacific Ocean, and the regional effects of climate change. In mid-January 2022, the Southern Cone had a severe heat wave, ... On January 10, the temperatures were 'particularly anomalous' in the south of the Pampas region and the north of Patagonia. ... During the most intense week of the heat wave, Argentina imported energy from Brazil and Uruguay.

Country_with_Annotation.Argentina: This extreme weather event was associated with the Atlantic anticyclone, a particularly intense La Niña phenomenon in the Pacific Ocean, and the regional effects of climate change. ... During the wave, new electric energy consumption records were set at the national level, above 28,000 MW. ... In the midst of the heat wave, and after important fires registered in the previous weeks, especially in Patagonia, the national government declared a fire emergency throughout the country for one year.
Country_with_Annotation.Brazil: During the most intense week of the heat wave, Argentina imported energy from Brazil and Uruguay.
Country_with_Annotation.Paraguay: During the most intense week of the heat wave, Argentina imported energy from Brazil and Uruguay.
Country_with_Annotation.Uruguay: Initially, the Uruguayan Institute of Meteorology (INUMET) issued an alert for the heat wave in the north, center and west of the country, but on January 13 it was extended to the entire country. ... The heat wave affected the generation of wind power due to the lack of wind, which resulted in 50% of the electrical energy having to be generated with the thermal power stations of the National Administration of Power Plants and Electrical Transmissions (UTE). ... After four days of heat wave, the National Directorate of Firefighters reported more than 100 active fires in different parts of the country. ... This weather event intensified the drought, which had triggered a declaration of 'agricultural emergency' in December 2021.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: This article mentions a total of 3 deaths associated with the 2022 Southern Cone heat wave: 'Deaths: 3'.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: On January 12 the city saw 3 heat-related deaths.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The text does not provide specific information regarding the total economic loss or damage caused by the 2022 Southern Cone heat wave.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Bob was the first Atlantic tropical cyclone to be officially designated using a masculine name after the discontinuation of Joint Army/Navy Phonetic Alphabet names. Bob brought moderate damage to portions of the United States Gulf Coast and areas farther inland in July 1979. The storm was the first hurricane in the Gulf of Mexico to form in the month of July since 1959, and was the fifth tropical cyclone to form during the annual hurricane season. Though the origin of Bob can be traced back to a tropical wave near the western coast of Africa in late June, Bob formed from a tropical depression in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico on July 9.
Time_with_Annotation:
Formed: July 9, 1979 (July 9, 1979)
Dissipated: July 16, 1979 (July 16, 1979)

Country_with_Annotation.Louisiana: Bob made landfall west of Grand Isle, Louisiana, and rapidly weakened after moving inland.
Country_with_Annotation.Mississippi: The highest wind observation was taken on an oil rig off the coast of Louisiana, which clocked sustained winds at 63 mph (101 km/h). However, the strongest wind gust in association with the hurricane was measured in Bay St. Louis, Mississippi, at 64 mph (103 km/h).
Country_with_Annotation.Tennessee: The resulting depression drifted into southern Ohio and afterwards curved eastward.
Country_with_Annotation.Kentucky: The resulting depression drifted into southern Ohio and afterwards curved eastward.
Country_with_Annotation.Indiana: In Indiana, the remnants of Bob dropped heavy rainfall, peaking at 5.72 in (145 mm) at a station in Indiana University Bloomington.
Country_with_Annotation.Ohio: The resulting depression drifted into southern Ohio and afterwards curved eastward.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Bob also spawned eight tornadoes, with two causing significant damage. Overall, Bob was responsible for one death and $20 million in damage.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Lafitte, Louisiana, two men were blown off of the roof of a marina, and one of them was killed; this would be the only death associated with the hurricane.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Bob also spawned eight tornadoes, with two causing significant damage. Overall, Bob was responsible for one death and $20 million in damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The February flood of 1825, also known in Germany as the Great Hallig Flood (Große Halligflut), was a devastating flood that occurred from 3 to 5 February 1825 on the North Sea coast. About 800 people were drowned due to this flood (Paragraph 1). The sand spit Agger Tange was broken through, and the Limfjord got its western opening to the sea. Henceforth, North Jutland has been an island (Paragraph 2). In North Frisia, the unprotected islets, known as Halligen, were hit (Paragraph 3). In East Frisia, the town of Emden was particularly hard hit (Paragraph 4). In the Netherlands, the February flood was the worst natural disaster of the 19th century (Paragraph 5).
Time_with_Annotation: The February flood of 1825, also known in Germany as the Great Hallig Flood (Große Halligflut), was a devastating flood that occurred from 3 to 5 February 1825...

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation:
The February flood of 1825, also known in Germany as the Great Hallig Flood (Große Halligflut), was a devastating flood that occurred from 3 to 5 February 1825 on the North Sea coast in which about 800 people were drowned.
Particularly affected was the North Sea coast of Jutland, Slesvig and Germany.

The February flood of 1825, also known in Germany as the Great Hallig Flood (Große Halligflut), was a devastating flood that occurred from 3 to 5 February 1825 on the North Sea coast in which about 800 people were drowned.
Particularly affected was the North Sea coast of Jutland, Slesvig and Germany.
In North Frisia, the unprotected islets, known as Halligen, were hit. Many dykes had already been damaged in November the year before by a severe storm surge. The island of Pellworm was completely flooded.
In the Netherlands, the February flood was the worst natural disaster of the 19th century. Most of the dead and the worst damage occurred in Groningen, Friesland and Overijssel.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation:
Particularly affected was the North Sea coast of Jutland, Slesvig and Germany. The sand spit Agger Tange was broken through, and the Limfjord got its western opening to the sea. Henceforth, North Jutland has been an island.
In North Frisia, the unprotected islets, known as Halligen, were hit. Many dykes had already been damaged in November the year before by a severe storm surge. The island of Pellworm was completely flooded.
In East Frisia, the town of Emden was particularly hard hit. However, because the levees in the East Frisian area had been raised significantly in many places in the preceding years, the number of casualties, about 200, was smaller than it might have otherwise been.
In the Netherlands, the February flood was the worst natural disaster of the 19th century. Most of the dead and the worst damage occurred in Groningen, Friesland and Overijssel.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Sam was a powerful and long-lived Cape Verde hurricane that threatened Bermuda, lasting from late September through early October. It was the fifth longest-lasting intense Atlantic hurricane, as measured by accumulated cyclone energy, since reliable records began in 1966... Sam originated from a tropical wave that departed from the western coast of Africa on September 19... The system developed into a tropical depression on September 22... Intensification was initially slow, with the depression strengthening into Tropical Storm Sam a day later... Soon afterward, the structure of the cyclone quickly improved and rapid intensification began... Sam strengthened into a hurricane on September 24... Sam peaked on September 26 as a high-end Category 4 hurricane... The storm turned towards the northwest early on September 27... The hurricane began to weaken on October 2... Sam finally dropped below major hurricane status on October 3... The storm moved east-northeastward to northeastward, and then northward, with increasing forward speed while gradually losing strength, weakening to Category 1 status the following day... Sam completed its transition into an extratropical cyclone on October 5... Hurricane Sam remained a major hurricane for 7.75 days, which was longer than any other Atlantic system this season, and the longest since Hurricane Ivan in 2004.
Time_with_Annotation: Hurricane Sam was a powerful and long-lived Cape Verde hurricane that threatened Bermuda, lasting from late September through early October. ... Sam was the eighteenth named storm, seventh hurricane, and fourth major hurricane of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season. ... Sam originated from a tropical wave that departed from the western coast of Africa on September 19. The system developed into a tropical depression on September 22, as upper-level winds gradually became more favorable.

Country_with_Annotation.West Africa: Hurricane Sam originated from a tropical wave that departed from the western coast of Africa on September 19.
Country_with_Annotation.Lesser Antilles: Large swells produced by the hurricane affected portions of the Lesser Antilles through late-September.
Country_with_Annotation.Puerto Rico: While passing northeast of Puerto Rico, light winds associated with Sam’s circulation interacted with the typically moist environment and, in conjunction with the normal diurnal cycle, produced locally heavy rainfall on the island on September 28–29.
Country_with_Annotation.Bermuda: In Bermuda, tropical storm warnings and watches were raised on September 30 and remained in effect until October 2. Although the core of Sam remained east of the territory, its broadening wind field brought tropical storm-force winds to the area.
Country_with_Annotation.Iceland: Afterward, this new low made a large counterclockwise loop between Iceland and Greenland, before being absorbed by a stronger low on October 9, to the southwest of Iceland.
Country_with_Annotation.Greenland: Afterward, this new low made a large counterclockwise loop between Iceland and Greenland, before being absorbed by a stronger low on October 9, to the southwest of Iceland.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths associated with Hurricane Sam.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: While passing northeast of Puerto Rico, light winds associated with Sam’s circulation interacted with the typically moist environment and, in conjunction with the normal diurnal cycle, produced locally heavy rainfall on the island on September 28–29. Some street flooding occurred along roads with poor drainage and several mudslides were reported in western communities.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage: Minimal

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Isa was the first of a record eleven super typhoons to occur during the 1997 Pacific typhoon season. The second tropical cyclone of the season, Isa developed from a disturbance in the monsoon trough near the Caroline Islands on April 12... Isa very gradually intensified, and on April 20 the typhoon reached peak 1-min winds of 270 km/h (170 mph), as reported by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center; Japan Meteorological Agency reported maximum 10-min winds of 155 km/h (95 mph). After turning northward, it accelerated to the northeast, and merged with a larger extratropical cyclone on April 24.
Time_with_Annotation: The system maintained a persistent area of well-organized deep convection, and subsequent to an increase in upper-level outflow, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) classified the system as Tropical Depression 02W at 1800 UTC on April 11... Shortly thereafter, a large, yet weak low-level circulation formed within the system... Based on sufficient satellite classifications, JTWC upgraded the depression to Tropical Storm Isa early on April 12... The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) simultaneously classified the system as a tropical depression and upgraded it to a tropical storm early on April 13... JTWC upgraded the storm to typhoon status... JMA continued to assess Isa as a minimal tropical storm, and did not upgrade it to a typhoon until April 16... On April 20 JTWC classified Super Typhoon Isa as reaching peak 1-min winds of 270 km/h (170 mph)... JMA classified Isa dissipated as it became absorbed by a cloud band from a large extratropical cyclone to the east of Japan on April 24.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Early in its duration, Isa caused light rainfall and moderate winds on Pohnpei.
Later, a stationary rainband from the typhoon dropped heavy precipitation on Guam during its dry season.
Typhoon Isa later dropped light rainfall on the island of Rota.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 0

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: No deaths were reported.
No deaths were reported.
No deaths or injuries were reported.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Black Sunday is a particularly severe dust storm that occurred on April 14, 1935, as part of the Dust Bowl in the United States. It was one of the worst dust storms in American history and caused immense economic and agricultural damage. It is estimated that 300 thousand tons of topsoil were displaced from the prairie area. On the afternoon of April 14, residents of several plains states were forced to take cover as a dust storm or 'black blizzard' blew through the region. The storm first hit the Oklahoma panhandle and northwestern Oklahoma and moved south for the day. It hit Beaver, Oklahoma around 4 p.m., Boise City around 5:15, and Amarillo, Texas, at 7:20. The conditions were the most severe in the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles, but the storm's effects were also felt in surrounding areas. Drought, erosion, bare soil, and winds caused the dust to fly freely and at high speeds.

Country_with_Annotation.United States: It was one of the worst dust storms in American history and caused immense economic and agricultural damage. It is estimated that 300 thousand tons of topsoil were displaced from the prairie area. The storm first hit the Oklahoma panhandle and northwestern Oklahoma and moved south for the day. It hit Beaver, Oklahoma around 4 p.m., Boise City around 5:15, and Amarillo, Texas, at 7:20. The conditions were the most severe in the Oklahoma and  Texas panhandles, but the storm's effects were also felt in surrounding areas.

The conditions were the most severe in the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles, but the storm's effects were also felt in surrounding areas... The destruction caused by the dust storms, and especially by the storm on Black Sunday, killed multiple people [citation needed]...
