Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Leslie (known as Storm Leslie or Cyclone Leslie while extratropical) was the strongest cyclone of tropical origin to strike the Iberian Peninsula since 1842. A large, long-lived, and very erratic tropical cyclone, Leslie was the twelfth named storm and sixth hurricane of the 2018 Atlantic hurricane season. The storm had a non-tropical origin, developing from an extratropical cyclone that was situated over the northern Atlantic on 22 September. The low quickly acquired subtropical characteristics and was classified as Subtropical Storm Leslie on the following day... Leslie became fully tropical and gradually intensified, becoming a Category 1 hurricane early on 3 October... Leslie continued to slowly strengthen, reaching peak intensity with sustained winds of 150 km/h (90 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 968 mbar (28.59 inHg), early on 12 October... Leslie then began to gradually weaken later that day, while accelerating towards the northeast and passed far south of the Azores. On 13 October, Leslie passed north of Madeira, before transitioning into an extratropical cyclone just off the Portuguese coast later that day. Leslie's remnants made landfall in central Portugal a few hours later.
Time_with_Annotation:
Formed: 23 September 2018
Dissipated: 16 October 2018

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In November 2018, Aon estimated that Leslie's damage total exceeded â¬424 million (US$500 million). Hurricane Leslie prompted the issuance of tropical storm watches and warnings for Madeira Island. Leslie brought wind gusts up to 190 km/h (120 mph) to Portugal, felling thousands of trees, causing the collapse of hundreds of structures, and damaging hundreds of buildings, signs, and pieces of equipment. Over 300,000 citizens were left without power. Damage across the country was estimated to be â¬120 million (US$145 million). In November 2018, Aon estimated that Leslie's damage total exceeded â¬424 million (US$500 million). Hurricane Leslie was responsible for 17 deaths in mainland Europe, including 2 direct deaths in Portugal and 15 indirect deaths in France.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: As the cyclone reached the Portuguese Coast, it brought wind gusts of 190 km/h (120 mph); Leslie was considered the worst cyclone to affect Portugal since 1842. The strong gusts were attributed to the development of a sting jet. Leslie was only the second tropical cyclone to make landfall on the Iberian Peninsula since 1842, with the other storm being Hurricane Vince, which made landfall in southern Spain during 2005. Authorities in Lisbon requested that all residents remain indoors. Around 800 people took refuge in a concert hall in Figueira da Foz. Wind gusts of 176 km/h (109 mph) downed trees and traffic signs, with the former causing several traffic accidents. In the city, six vehicles were damaged by a collapsing building, and another five were damaged by falling trees. Multiple homes in the area were deroofed.

The Leclerc promenade in SÃ¨te was closed due to 7.6 m (25 ft)-high surf and 111 km/h (69 mph) wind gusts. At least 15 people were killed throughout the Aude as a result of the floods: six in TrÃ¨bes, three in Villegailhenc, two in Villalier, one in Veillardonnel, one in Carcassonne, and one in Saint-Couat-d'Aude. At least 75 additional people were injured in the department. Flooding interrupted railway traffic along the BÃ©ziers-Narbonne section and other routes in Carcassonne. Several roads in Carcassonne were blocked by felled trees, and cars were either swept away by floodwaters or destroyed. Schools and universities throughout the city were closed from 15 to 16 October. In the villages surrounding Carcassonne, flash flooding overturned vehicles, damaged roadways, and caused homes to collapse. Multiple waterspouts occurred near the region bordering Spain.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Aon estimated that Leslie's damage total exceeded €424 million (US$500 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Extratropical cyclone Burglind, named Eleanor in the UK and Ireland, caused significant damage across Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom between 2nd and 3rd January 2018.
Time_with_Annotation: Extratropical cyclone Burglind, named Eleanor in the UK and Ireland, caused significant damage across Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom between 2nd and 3rd January 2018.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths associated with Burglind|Eleanor.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The estimate of insurance and reinsurance industry losses caused by European windstorm Burglind, which was known as Eleanor in the United Kingdom and Ireland, has risen to EUR 756 million (US $860m), a 4.4% increase.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Matthew was an extremely powerful Atlantic hurricane which caused catastrophic damage and a humanitarian crisis in Haiti, as well as widespread devastation in the southeastern United States. The deadliest Atlantic hurricane since Hurricane Stan in 2005, and the first Category 5 Atlantic hurricane since Felix in 2007, Matthew was the thirteenth named storm, fifth hurricane and second major hurricane of the 2016 Atlantic hurricane season... Matthew caused extensive damage to landmasses in the Greater Antilles, and severe damage in several islands of the Bahamas... Matthew also approached the southeastern United States, but stayed just offshore, paralleling the Florida coastline.

Country_with_Annotation.Windward Islands: On September 27, prior to Matthew becoming a tropical cyclone, LIAT began cancelling flights across the Windward Islands in anticipation of squally weather.
Country_with_Annotation.South America: The storm's unusual south track prompted the issuance of tropical storm watches on September 28 for Aruba, Bonaire, Curaçao, and the northern coast of Colombia from the Colombia–Venezuela border to Riohacha.
Country_with_Annotation.Jamaica: With Matthew posing a significant threat to Jamaica, emergency officials ordered all fishermen on the nation's cays and banks to evacuate to the mainland on September 29.
Country_with_Annotation.Haiti: Though forecast to pass over Jamaica at the time, the large extent of tropical storm-force winds prompted the issuance of a tropical storm watch for Haiti's Tiburon Peninsula toward the border with the Dominican Republic.
Country_with_Annotation.Dominican Republic: On the morning of October 2, a tropical storm warning was raised for the southern coast of the Dominican Republic from Barahona west to the Haitian border, and a tropical storm watch was issued for the northern coast from Puerto Plata west to the Haitian border.
Country_with_Annotation.Cuba: The Meteorological Service of Cuba raised hurricane watches for all of southeastern Cuba on October 1, encompassing the provinces of Camagüey, Las Tunas, Granma, Holguín, Santiago de Cuba, and Guantánamo.
Country_with_Annotation.Bahamas: The Government of the Bahamas began issuing hurricane watches on October 2 for southeastern islands as well as the Turks and Caicos.
Country_with_Annotation.United States: On October 3, the governors of Florida and North Carolina declared a state of emergency.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: According to the nation's Civil Protection Directorate, the death toll in Haiti was 546 as of October 14, with 128 people missing and 439 injured. In the United States, Hurricane Matthew killed 47 people, including 26 in North Carolina, 12 in Florida, 3 in Georgia, 4 in South Carolina, and 2 in Virginia. In Dominican Republic, four people died after a house collapsed on top of them due to flooding. In Cuba, no fatalities were reported despite the severity of damage. However, nearly two months later, a municipal bridge in the city of Moa that was damaged by Hurricane Matthew collapsed, killing four employees of Canadian mining company Sherritt International.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Charley (1998) was a weather event that formed on August 21, 1998, and dissipated on August 24, 1998. It originated from a tropical wave that moved off the West African coast on August 9. The storm formed in the southeastern Gulf of Mexico and made landfall near Port Aransas, Texas. Charley produced heavy rainfall, with a 90-mile (140 km) wide swath of over 3 inches (76 mm) of rainfall extending from the Middle Texas Coast west to the Texas-Mexico border. The storm caused $50 million (1998 USD) in damage and resulted in 20 direct fatalities, all from drowning.
Time_with_Annotation: The storm originated with a tropical wave that moved off the West African coast on August 9... Hurricane Hunter investigations into the system the next day revealed that this was not the case... early on the morning of August 21, when advisories were initiated on the tropical depression... The storm moved slowly inland and finally dissipated on the morning of the August 24 near the town of Del Rio, Texas.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: Charley's impacts in Texas and Mexico were locally severe. In Texas, over 2000 homes were destroyed by the locally severe flooding, and 13 people died.
In Mexico, over 12 inches (300 mm) of rain fell in northern areas near the Texas-Mexico border, and seven people were killed.
Several inches of rain fell in parts of Louisiana. Lake Charles, Louisiana received the most, with 1.2 inches (30 mm).

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Charley caused $50 million (1998 USD) in damage across southern Texas.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nari (pronounced [na.ɾi]), known in the Philippines as Typhoon Santi, was a strong and deadly tropical cyclone that first struck Luzon before striking Vietnam. The storm was the 41st depression and the 8th typhoon in the 2013 typhoon season. Typhoon Nari was a deadly typhoon that made landfall in the Philippines and Vietnam. Nari made landfall on October 14, 2013 as a moderate category 1 typhoon.
Time_with_Annotation: On October 8, 2013 the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) started to monitor a tropical depression, that developed within an area of low to moderate vertical windshear, about 1,150 km (715 mi) to the southwest of Manila on the Philippine island of Luzon.
Early on October 16, both the JMA and JTWC issued their final warnings on Nari, as the system dissipated.

Country_with_Annotation.Philippines: Typhoon Nari (pronounced [na.ɾi]), known in the Philippines as Typhoon Santi, was a strong and deadly tropical cyclone that first struck Luzon before striking Vietnam. ... Nari made landfall on October 14, 2013 as a moderate category 1 typhoon.[citation needed] ... During October 9, PAGASA issued the public storm warning signal number 1 for the island province of Catanduanes, before expanding the areas under Signal 1 early the next day to include Aurora, Camarines Norte, Camarines Sur, Isabela, the Polillo Islands and Quezon.[9][10][11] ... Within the Philippines a total of 15 people were left dead while 5 were missing, while total economic losses were amounted to be Php 12.3 billion (US$277.34 million).[8]
Country_with_Annotation.Vietnam: The storm was the 41st depression and the 8th typhoon in the 2013 typhoon season. Typhoon Nari was a deadly typhoon that made landfall in the Philippines and Vietnam. ... Nari made landfall on October 14, 2013 as a moderate category 1 typhoon.[citation needed] ... In advance of the typhoon, more than 122,000 residents were evacuated from vulnerable provinces to higher grounds. Thousands of travelers were left stranded as Vietnam Airlines cancelled over a dozen flights.[17] ... In total Nari caused 26 deaths and economic losses of 4,315 billion VND (US$204.5 million, 2013)
Country_with_Annotation.Laos: On October 16, poor weather from the remnants of Typhoon Nari has been cited as a probable cause for the crash of Lao Airlines Flight 301, on approach to Pakse International Airport with the loss of all 49 passengers and crew.[19] Another 4 people were killed directly due to the storm.[16]
Country_with_Annotation.China: Total damages in China were counted to be CN¥50 million (US$8.19 million).[20]

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 93 total

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage: $289.6 million (2013 USD)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Sinlaku was a weak tropical cyclone that impacted Vietnam, Thailand and Laos in August 2020. Beginning as a tropical depression on July 31 in the South China Sea, Sinlaku was the fifth storm of the 2020 Pacific typhoon season. It gradually organized as it took a slow west-northwest course, strengthening into a tropical storm the following day despite its monsoonal structure.
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: July 31, 2020
Dissipated: August 3, 2020

Country_with_Annotation.Philippines: The low-pressure area associated with Sinlaku dumped heavy rain over regions of Luzon and Visayas in the Philippines. After crossing Luzon, the storm exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility but intensified the monsoon.
Country_with_Annotation.Vietnam: Sinlaku caused heavy rains across northern Vietnam, damaging more than 4,000 hectares of crops and over 9,000 hectares of rice crops. The storm damaged over 1,400 houses, with 32 houses being flooded with 30-40 centimeters. Two people were dead, 1 in both Hoa Binh and Quang Ninh provinces, and two were injured in the province of Lam Dong. A thunderstorm from the storm broke 29 trees in districts of Hanoi. Total damages were about 300 billion đồng (US$12.94 million).
Country_with_Annotation.Thailand: Moving towards Thailand, Sinlaku's heavy rains caused flash flooding which two people were killed. In Loei Province, the storm brought heavy rains and flash flooding, submerging around 550 households and damaging farmland in the province. In total, 1,399 households were affected by the flash floods.
Country_with_Annotation.Laos: In Xayaboury Province, more than 1,000 people were affected and over 200 houses were damaged.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Sinlaku brought heavy monsoonal rains to much of Southeast Asia, especially to Vietnam, Laos, and Thailand. Two people were killed in Vietnam, and two people were killed in Thailand.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Nghệ An Province, Hoa Binh, Quang Ninh provinces
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Nearing the northern coast, Sinlaku caused heavy rains across the area, damaging more than 4,000 hectares of crops and over 9,000 hectares of rice crops. The storm damaged over 1,400 houses, with 32 houses being flooded with 30-40 centimeters. Two people were dead, 1 in both Hoa Binh and Quang Ninh provinces, and two were injured in the province of Lam Dong.
Moving towards Thailand, Sinlaku's heavy rains caused flash flooding which two people were killed.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: On January 13, 2013, an extratropical cyclone formed northeast of Taiwan and quickly intensified, reaching its peak intensity east of Japan on January 15 with central atmospheric pressure decreasing to 936 hPa (27.6 inHg). The system then weakened, crossed the Kamchatka Peninsula late on January 18, and dissipated east of Hokkaido on January 21.
Time_with_Annotation: {"Text": "The January 2013 Northwest Pacific cyclone was a powerful extratropical cyclone which caused heavy rainfall and a severe blizzard in Japan in January 2013. Forming northeast of Taiwan on January 13...", "Source": "Formed: January 13, 2013"}

Country_with_Annotation.Taiwan: The January 2013 Northwest Pacific cyclone formed northeast of Taiwan on January 13
Country_with_Annotation.Japan: the storm quickly intensified in the southern sea off Japan on January 14, and reached its peak intensity east of Japan on January 15... The powerful extratropical cyclone which passed over the sea south of Japan caused heavy rainfall and snowfall in the country on January 14... About 1600 injuries were recorded in Japan... In Shiojiri, a 71-year-old man died after falling into an open drain as he cleared snow around his house... A large chunk of frozen snow fell from the Tokyo Skytree and crashed into the roof of a house below, leaving a 30 cm (12 in) hole... As January 14 was also Coming of Age Day in 2013, many young Japanese people who were celebrating their 20th year had to walk through heavy snowfall to attend Coming of Age Day ceremonies.
Country_with_Annotation.Russian Far East: The system then weakened, crossed the Kamchatka Peninsula late on January 18, and dissipated east of Hokkaido on January 21.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: There is no specific information in the article regarding the total economic loss or damage caused by the January 2013 Northwest Pacific cyclone.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Very Severe Cyclonic Storm Ockhi was a strong tropical cyclone that devastated parts of Sri Lanka and India in 2017, and was the most intense tropical cyclone in the Arabian Sea since Cyclone Megh in 2015. The ninth depression, and the third and strongest named storm of the 2017 North Indian Ocean cyclone season, Ockhi originated from an area of low pressure that formed over the southwest Bay of Bengal on November 28. The storm organized into a Depression off southeast coast of Sri Lanka on November 29, causing damage to property and life in Sri Lanka while passing by. Due to high atmospheric moisture and warmer oceanic surface temperature between Sri Lanka and Kanyakumari (Cape Comorin) in mainland India, Ockhi intensified into a cyclonic storm on November 30.
Time_with_Annotation: On November 28, an area of low pressure from the remnant energy of Tropical Storm Kirogi developed about 425 km (265 mi) to the south-southeast of Colombo, Sri Lanka. [...] The storm tracked along Sri Lanka's southwestern and western coastline, towards the west-northwest, around the southern verge of a subtropical ridge located over India. [...] Ockhi weakened into a well-marked low near the south coast of Gujarat, India, on December 6, before crossing the coastline and dissipating shortly afterward.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: The system produced heavy rainfall and gale-force winds in Sri Lanka, initially affecting the southern coastline, with Matara, and the general Matara District in particular, experiencing wind speeds of 70–80 km/h (40–50 mph) and bearing the brunt of the cyclone.
The Maldives Meteorological Centre predicted heavy rain and strong winds across the country’s atolls, particularly those in the north and center of the island chain, over the day.

Cyclone Ockhi passed just south of Puthalam, the southern tip of mainland India, on November 30. Though it turned to northeast and headed towards the Lakshadweep Islands in the Arabian Sea, it caused havoc and destruction in the southernmost districts of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, particularly the Kanyakumari District of Tamil Nadu and the Thiruvananthapuram District of Kerala.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The system left a trail of massive destruction in Sri Lanka, Lakshadweep, South India, and The Maldives, as it strengthened from a depression to a mature cyclone. Though it rapidly weakened during its final stages over the Arabian Sea, it caused at least 245 fatalities, including 218 in India and 27 in Sri Lanka.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The system produced heavy rainfall and gale-force winds in Sri Lanka, initially affecting the southern coastline, with Matara, and the general Matara District in particular, experiencing wind speeds of 70–80 km/h (40–50 mph) and bearing the brunt of the cyclone.

Cyclone Ockhi passed just south of Puthalam, the southern tip of mainland India, on November 30. Though it turned to northeast and headed towards the Lakshadweep Islands in the Arabian Sea, it caused havoc and destruction in the southernmost districts of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, particularly the Kanyakumari District of Tamil Nadu and the Thiruvananthapuram District of Kerala.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The government sought a relief package, worth ₹ 7,340 crore (US$1.14 billion).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Columbus Day storm of 1962 was a Pacific Northwest windstorm that struck the West Coast of Canada and the Pacific Northwest coast of the United States on October 12, 1962. The storm is considered to be the benchmark of extratropical wind storms and ranks among the most intense to strike the region since at least 1948. It is a contender for the title of the most powerful extratropical cyclone recorded in the U.S. in the 20th century, with respect to wind velocity. The system brought strong winds to the Pacific Northwest and southwest Canada, and was linked to 46 fatalities in the northwest and Northern California resulting from heavy rains and mudslides.
Time_with_Annotation: On October 12, 1962, the extratropical low redeveloped intensely off the coast of Northern California... The storm then raced nearly northward at an average speed of 40 miles per hour (64 km/h), with the center situated just 50 miles (80 km) off the Pacific Coast... On October 13, the center passed over Tatoosh Island, Washington, before making landfall on Vancouver Island, British Columbia, where it weakened rapidly.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least 46 fatalities were attributed to this storm, more than for any other Pacific Northwest weather event.[10] In terms of natural disaster-related fatalities for the 20th century, only Oregon's Heppner Flood of 1903 (247 deaths), Washington's Wellington avalanche of 1910 (96 deaths), the Great Fire of 1910 (87 deaths), and Eruption of Mount St. Helens of 1980 (57 deaths) caused more.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Central and Northern California, all-time record rains associated with the atmospheric river along the cold front caused major flooding and mudslides, particularly in the San Francisco Bay Area. Heavy rain forced Game 6 of the 1962 World Series at San Francisco's Candlestick Park to be postponed from its originally scheduled date of October 11 to Monday, October 15.

In the Willamette Valley, it is said the undamaged home was the exception. Livestock suffered greatly due to the barn failures: the animals were crushed under the weight of the collapsed structures, a story that was repeated many times throughout the afflicted region.
The state capitol grounds at Salem, and the state's college campuses, resembled battlefields with heavy losses of trees.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Campbell Hall tower at Oregon College of Education (now Western Oregon University) in Monmouth
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The Campbell Hall tower at Oregon College of Education (now Western Oregon University) in Monmouth crashed to the ground, an event recorded by student photographer Wes Luchau in the most prominent picture-symbol of the storm.
East of Salem, the wind destroyed a historic barn that served as a clandestine meeting place by pro-slavery Democratic members of the state Legislature in 1860.
Five people in British Columbia were killed in the storm, and the area suffered $80 million in damages. Stanley Park lost 3,000 trees.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Estimates put the dollar damage at approximately $230 million to $280 million for California, Oregon, and Washington combined.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Very Severe Cyclonic Storm Hikaa was a tropical cyclone that struck eastern Oman in September 2019. The storm reached peak intensity on September 24, with maximum sustained winds estimated over 140 km/h (85 mph). The name Hikaa was named by Maldives, which refers to the 'scorpion' in Maldivian. An area of convection, or thunderstorms, persisted along the west coast of India on September 19... A distinct low-pressure area developed a day later off the coast of Maharashtra... By September 21, a circulation was consolidating within the system, located east of the heaviest convection. The system moved slowly westward across the Arabian Sea, steered by a ridge to north. Warm water temperatures favored further development, despite moderate wind shear... Early on September 22, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) designated the system as a depression, and soon upgraded it to a deep depression... Late on September 22, the American-based Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) initiated advisories on the system, designating it Tropical Cyclone 03A... Due to decreasing wind shear and warm, moist air, the system quickly intensified on September 23... The IMD upgraded the system to Cyclonic Storm Hikaa; later that day the agency upgraded the storm further to a severe cyclonic storm... Considering the storm a 'midget tropical cyclone', the JTWC upgraded Hikaa to the equivalent of hurricane status late on September 23... The IMD upgraded Hikaa to a very severe cyclonic storm on September 24, estimating peak winds of 140 km/h (85 mph)... Around 14:00 UTC on September 24, Hikaa made landfall in eastern Oman just north of Duqm, becoming the first very severe cyclonic storm on record to strike the country in September.
Time_with_Annotation: An area of convection, or thunderstorms, persisted along the west coast of India on September 19... Late on September 22, the American-based Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) initiated advisories on the system, designating it Tropical Cyclone 03A... Around 14:00 UTC on September 24, Hikaa made landfall in eastern Oman just north of Duqm... Early on September 25, the IMD downgraded Hikaa to a deep depression, and later to a low-pressure area, by which time the storm was near the border of Oman and Saudi Arabia.

Country_with_Annotation.India: An area of convection, or thunderstorms, persisted along the west coast of India on September 19.
Country_with_Annotation.Oman: Around 14:00 UTC on September 24, Hikaa made landfall in eastern Oman just north of Duqm, becoming the first very severe cyclonic storm on record to strike the country in September.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 5

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: A deep-sea fishing boat with a crew of 11 capsized off of Masirah Island during the storm; there were five confirmed fatalities from the shipwreck, and one person was rescued.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Tanya was the first named storm to start with a 'T' in the Atlantic since naming began in 1950, and the final storm of the very active 1995 Atlantic hurricane season. The twenty-first tropical cyclone, nineteenth named storm, and eleventh hurricane of the season, Tanya developed from a tropical wave while well north of the Lesser Antilles on October 26. The system headed northeastward and strengthened into Tropical Storm Tanya on October 27. Tanya meandered around the central Atlantic, and further intensified into a hurricane on October 29. After switching to an eastward direction, Tanya weakened to a tropical storm on November 1 and passed through the Azores as it was transitioning into an extratropical cyclone.
Time_with_Annotation: The system headed northeastward and strengthened into Tropical Storm Tanya on October 27... Hurricane Tanya was also heading rapidly northeast towards the Azores at the time... Tanya was downgraded from a hurricane to a tropical storm on November 1... The remnant cyclone turned north, before being absorbed by another extratropical cyclone early on November 3.

Country_with_Annotation.Azores: Throughout the Azores, the extratropical remnants of Tanya produced high winds... As a result, extensive property damage occurred, which included destroyed or damaged houses, and sunken boats; there were also reports of significant damage to agriculture.
Country_with_Annotation.Portugal: After the storm, a resolution was submitted to the European Parliament by the Government of Portugal and a disaster area was declared in the islands.
Country_with_Annotation.Spain: One Spanish fisherman drowned and several people were injured.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Throughout the Azores, the extratropical remnants of Tanya produced high winds... As a result, extensive property damage occurred, which included destroyed or damaged houses, and sunken boats; there were also reports of significant damage to agriculture. However, an exact damage toll figure is unknown. In addition, there was one fatality and several injuries.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The Azores were hit very hard by the storm, which had just been declared extratropical when it hit the region... One Spanish fisherman drowned and several people were injured.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage: Minimal

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation:
Cyclone Carmen (or Windstorm Carmen) was an extratropical cyclone and European windstorm which crossed the Atlantic Ocean and affected the United Kingdom, Ireland, France, Belgium, and the Netherlands in November 2010.
Paragraph: Windstorm Carmen formed as a low-pressure system off the east coast of the United States.
Paragraph: By 9 November, while over Nova Scotia, the system was named 'Carmen' as it passed into the North Atlantic near and over southern Greenland, Iceland, and the Faroe Islands, which had been suffering from the lesser windstorm Becky since the 5th.
Paragraph: Traveling eastward, Carmen eventually attained a central pressure of 948 mb as it struck the United Kingdom.
Paragraph: Carmen was last noted over western Russia on 14 November 2010, as it continued to weaken, and had burnt itself out over the Former Yugoslavia, Eastern Europe, Moscow, and the Gulf of Finland between 18 and 19 November 2010.
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: 7 November 2010
Dissipated: 19 November 2010

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: High winds and rough seas battered the western coastline of Ireland on the nights of 7–8 November 2010.

Details.Impact_Details: High winds, heavy rain, flooding, and snow affected Ireland. Two fatalities occurred due to weather-related road conditions, and a Brazilian man drowned in a car accident caused by flooding. The water levels at Galway Docks and the Claddagh Basin rose violently, and County Cork was hit by minor flooding. A van and a bus carrying 27 students from County Mayo to Limerick skidded on groundwater and crashed, killing both drivers and injuring 12 of the students.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: Traveling eastward, Carmen eventually attained a central pressure of 949 millibars as it struck the United Kingdom.

Details.Impact_Details: High winds, heavy rain, flooding, and snow affected the United Kingdom. A major HSE rail investigation was launched after a morning commuter train skidded on wet leaves. There were gusts of 65 mph (105 km/h) at Berry Head in Devon and 60 mph (97 km/h) in Dundrennan, Dumfries and Galloway. Blackpool Tower suffered structural damage, and approximately 5,000 people were left without electricity in Northern Ireland.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: On the evening of the 8th, 28-year-old kitesurfer Adrien Monnoyeur from Toulouse ignored safety warnings and was killed as a gale in the Saint Jean de Luz resort, near Biarritz in southwest France, dragged him at 100 mph (160 km/h) across the beach and fatally slammed him down from 50 ft (15 m) in the air onto the beach, after hitting the Grand Hotel and a local pier en route.

Details.Impact_Details: A kitesurfer was killed due to high winds and a gale in southwest France.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: On November 12, many Belgian rivers and canals rose above the national alarm level, with some of their defenses failing. Four deaths occurred over the weekend in Belgium.

Details.Impact_Details: Heavy rain caused rivers and canals to rise above the national alarm level, resulting in four deaths and flooding in various parts of the country. The River Dendre flooded Brussels heavily, reaching 46 cm above alarm level along with several canals. Flood defenses failed in places, and 200 houses were evacuated.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: In continental Europe, high winds caused the Karneval festivities in Cologne and elsewhere in the Rhineland to be cut short. The St. Martin's Day procession was cancelled in Aachen and minor flooding and high winds occurred in various parts of Germany, but no one was injured.

Details.Impact_Details: High winds caused the cancellation of Karneval festivities and the St. Martin's Day procession. Minor flooding and high winds occurred in various parts of Germany, but no one was injured.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: Floods and heavy rainfall also began in the Netherlands on the 14th.

Details.Impact_Details: Heavy rains caused flooding in several towns in the Netherlands, including Limburg and North Brabant province.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: There is no specific information about the total economic loss or damage caused by Cyclone Carmen in the provided article.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Fiona was a large, powerful, and destructive Category 4 Atlantic hurricane which was the costliest and most intense tropical or post-tropical cyclone to hit Canada on record. It was the sixth named storm, third hurricane and first major hurricane of the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season.
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: September 14, 2022; Dissipated: September 27, 2022

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least 29 deaths have been confirmed throughout the Caribbean and Canada from Hurricane Fiona as of September 30.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: One person died when his house was washed away in the floods near the Rivière des Pères in the district of Basse-Terre.
At least 21 deaths in Puerto Rico have been attributed to the hurricane.
At least 2 people were killed in the Dominican Republic.
A Port aux Basques woman was killed when her home was destroyed and she was swept into the ocean.
Another person died of carbon monoxide poisoning while operating an electrical generator.
Another man in Lower Prospect, Nova Scotia was swept out to sea and presumed dead.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: A large disturbance formed near the Northern Mariana Islands late on September 9. Late on September 11, the JMA reported that the disturbance intensified to a tropical depression had developed about 565 km (350 mi) to the northeast of Saipan, in the Northern Mariana Islands. It was designated as 16W by the JTWC and JMA upgraded to a tropical storm naming it Man-yi on September 13, moving north then west on September 13. Man-yi still started intensifying and grew larger more later that day as it dropped a pressure of 20 millibars. Late on September 14, Man-yi became a severe tropical storm, absorbing few dry air and making a small unbalanced eye. Man-yi started moving towards Japan making more strong winds to Japan on September 15 and made landfall on September 16 near Toyohashi, Aichi Prefecture. Typhoon Man-yi became extratropical on September 16 and fully dissipated late on September 20 in the Kamchatka Peninsula region, bringing strong winds until September 25.

Country_with_Annotation.Japan: Typhoon Man-yi was a very severe storm that brought very strong winds and flash floods to Japan during mid-September. ... Japan was then experiencing winds above 30 knots. ... During September 14, as winds started to get stronger, evacuations were ordered to many places in Japan. ... Hundreds of thousands of others were also ordered to evacuate across mainly the west side of Japan. ... Over 70 people were injured and at least one person was killed. ... Many homes were flooded and about 80,000 were without electricity in western and central Japan. ... Trains in Tokyo and its vicinity were mostly suspended and hundreds of flights were grounded. ... The storm made its first landfall in Toyohashi, Aichi Prefecture in 08:00am on September 15 as 2 people were reported dead and 6 missing. ... During the morning hours of September 16, another 4 people were dead by falling trees, landslides and flashfloods. ... In Osaka, about 290,000 residents in the city's harbor area were forced to flee early Monday.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 6 total

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Toyohashi, Aichi Prefecture; Osaka; Kyoto; Mie; Nara
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The storm made its first landfall in Toyohashi, Aichi Prefecture in 08:00am on September 15 as 2 people were reported dead and 6 missing. During the morning hours of September 16, another 4 people were dead by falling trees, landslides and flashfloods... In Osaka, about 290,000 residents in the city's harbor area were forced to flee early Monday... In Kyoto on September 16, 260,000 people in the city were ordered to evacuate to shelters... Precipitation in the 48 hours through Monday morning reached about 300 mm in parts of the cities of Kyoto and Otsu — more than they usually get for the entire month. Precipitation topped 500 mm in parts of Mie and Nara, the agency said.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage across Japan were huge, total loss reached ¥160 billion (US$1.62 billion).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane San Roque was a destructive tropical cyclone in August 1893 that primarily affected Puerto Rico, eastern New England, and Atlantic Canada. Its informal name in Puerto Rico arises from the feast day of Saint Roch, or San Roque in Spanish, which coincided with the hurricane's landfall on that island... It was the third known hurricane of the 1893 Atlantic hurricane season... The system was first observed on August 13 at low latitudes east of the Lesser Antilles... It grew to be a powerful, slow-moving hurricane in the Caribbean Sea... On August 17, it struck Puerto Rico at the equivalence of Category 3 on the modern-day Saffir–Simpson scale... The eye crossed the island from southeast to northwest in about seven hours... Later that day, the now-rapidly moving cyclone made landfall in Nova Scotia... The official Atlantic hurricane reanalysis project found no conclusive evidence of hurricane-force winds in Canada.

Country_with_Annotation.Lesser Antilles: The intensifying hurricane brought stormy conditions to the Lesser Antilles from Martinique to the Virgin Islands. In Saint Thomas, boats and docks were damaged, trees were blown down, and houses were unroofed.
Country_with_Annotation.Puerto Rico: For the first time in Puerto Rico's history, warning flags were used to alert the public of the approaching hurricane. Officials in San Juan first hoisted cautionary red flags during the mid-morning on August 16, upgraded three hours later to more urgent yellow and blue signals, and finally to black flags to mark the cyclone's onslaught.
Country_with_Annotation.New England: A closer pass by New England the following day resulted in severe nor'easter-like conditions, with winds peaking at 72 mph (116 km/h) on Block Island and 52 mph (84 km/h) on Nantucket.
Country_with_Annotation.Atlantic Canada: Though in a weakened state, the cyclone battered the Atlantic provinces of Canada. Writing for Cape Breton's Magazine, Michael L. MacDonald wrote that it was 'one of the most notorious marine storms in the history of Nova Scotia'.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The greatest maritime tragedy was the wreck of the steamship Dorcas and its barge, Etta Stewart, which struck a rocky shoal while underway east of Halifax. Dorcas capsized and was driven ashore, while the barge broke up in the pounding surf. All crew members and passengers on the two vessels, totaling 24 people, were killed. Two more people died when their boat sank on Trinity Bay in Newfoundland, for a storm total of 37 fatalities.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The hurricane caused four known fatalities in Puerto Rico.

After hitting the rocks, the steamer overturned, losing its engine, boilers, and cargo, and came to rest inverted on the beach. The barge broke up, littering the shore with timbers. All crew-members and passengers, totaling 24 people, were killed.
The sinking of a boat in Trinity Bay resulted in the drowning deaths of two men, including member of the General Assembly of Newfoundland, David C. Webber.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage: Unknown

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone John was an intense tropical cyclone that rapidly deepened offshore before devastating areas of Western Australia. The system was the second cyclone and first severe tropical cyclone of the active 1999-00 Australian region cyclone season. Cyclone John developed from a monsoon trough positioned northwest of Australia on 9 December 1999... Cyclone John extensively affected areas of Western Australia, but damage was not as bad as expected... The system was responsible for no deaths and a limited amount of damage.

Country_with_Annotation.Australia: Severe Tropical Cyclone John was an intense tropical cyclone that rapidly deepened offshore before devastating areas of Western Australia... Cyclone John extensively affected areas of Western Australia, but damage was not as bad as expected... The system was responsible for no deaths and a limited amount of damage.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: There were no fatalities associated with Cyclone John according to the article.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Rough seas from John also caused a maximum storm surge height of 2 m (6.6 ft), recorded in Port Hedland by the Port Hedland Authority on 15 December. Overall John was responsible for no deaths and a limited amount of damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Melor, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Nona, was a powerful tropical cyclone that struck the Philippines in December 2015. The twenty-seventh named storm and the eighteenth typhoon of the annual typhoon season, Melor killed 51 people and caused ₱7.04 billion (US$148.3 million) in damage.
Time_with_Annotation: During December 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency started to monitor a tropical depression, that had developed about 665 km (415 mi) to the south of Guam. [...] Several of meteorological agencies downgraded Melor to a tropical depression early on December 17, including the JMA and JTWC, who issued final warnings on the system; however, satellite imageries depicted an open trough instead of a discernable LLCC. The system completely dissipated in the Sulu Sea before noon.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Melor killed 51 people and caused ₱7.04 billion (US$148.3 million) in damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Niran was a very powerful tropical cyclone that brought severe impacts to extreme Northeastern Australia and nearly made landfall in New Caledonia in February and March 2021. The storm formed from a tropical low in the Coral Sea on 27 February and intensified into a Category 5 tropical cyclone on both the Australian region and the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale (SSHWS), at 12:00 UTC on 5 March, displaying a well-defined pinhole eye. Niran caused extensive damage in New Caledonia during its close passage, with winds of up to 150 km/h (95 mph) affecting portions of the country. Two people were injured in New Caledonia, and over 69,000 total customers lost power in the country.

Country_with_Annotation.Queensland: The cyclone formed from a tropical low in the Coral Sea on 27 February... The tropical low gradually intensified while stalling offshore of Queensland for several days... Early on 3 March, Niran pulled away from the coast of Australia... In the far-north region of the state, some banana crops were wiped out by Niran in its early phase... Two people were rescued from floodwaters.
Country_with_Annotation.New Caledonia: Soon afterward, Niran initiated an eyewall replacement cycle and encountered some wind shear, causing the storm to weaken on 6 March, as it passed just to the south of Grande Terre, the main island of New Caledonia... Niran caused extensive damage in New Caledonia during its close passage...
Country_with_Annotation.Vanuatu: High waves were also expected to affect Vanuatu, with wave heights up to 8 metres (26 ft) forecasted... Heavy rain from the cyclone was also briefly forecasted to impact Vanuatu.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: None

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Total economic losses reached $200 million (2021 USD).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nora, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Luming, was tied for the fourth-most intense tropical cyclone on record. Originating from an area of low pressure over the western Pacific, Nora was first identified as a tropical depression on October 2, 1973. Tracking generally westward, the system gradually intensified, attaining typhoon status the following evening... Nora subsequently weakened and turned northwestward as it approached the Philippines... After brushing Luzon on October 7, the system passed south of Taiwan and ultimately made landfall in China on October 10... Once onshore, Nora quickly weakened and dissipated the following day.
Time_with_Annotation: On September 30, a weak surface low developed within the monsoon trough about 195 km (120 mi) south of Yap... Later that day, aircraft reconnaissance revealed the system to have intensified into a tropical storm, at which time it was assigned the name Nora... By the evening of October 5, Nora had attained winds in excess of 260 km/h (160 mph)... Nora made landfall near Xiamen, Fujian as a minimal typhoon early on October 10. Once onshore, the storm rapidly degenerated into an area of low pressure before dissipating the following day.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The Philippines and Taiwan sustained the most extensive losses from Typhoon Nora, with 36 people losing their lives collectively.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Across the Philippines, 24 people were killed and over 1 million were left homeless.
Twelve people lost their lives and twenty-eight others were reported missing.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage in the country reached $2 million (1973 USD).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: On 4 November 196
Time_with_Annotation: On 4 November 1966, an abnormal occurrence of high tides, rain-swollen rivers and a severe sirocco wind caused the canals to rise to a height of 194 cm or 6 ft 4 in.

Country_with_Annotation.Italy: On 4 November 1966, an abnormal occurrence of high tides, rain-swollen rivers and a severe sirocco wind caused the canals to rise to a height of 194 cm or 6 ft 4 in.[1] Although Venice is known for its acque alte or high waters which often flood the streets, this flood left thousands of residents without homes and caused over six million dollars worth of damage to the various works of art throughout Venice.[2] The city remained isolated for 24 hours, and having been unprepared for this type of emergency, more than 75 percent of  businesses, shops, and artisans' studios, along with thousands of goods, were either seriously damaged or destroyed completely.[3] Other Italian cities in Northern and Central Italy, such as Florence, Trento, and Siena, were all affected by the weather, but Venice was the most severely affected.[3]

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths directly or indirectly caused by the 1966 Venice flood.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Although Venice is known for its acque alte or high waters which often flood the streets, this flood left thousands of residents without homes and caused over six million dollars worth of damage to the various works of art throughout Venice.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Numerous intense bushfires occurred in September 2019 in north eastern New South Wales, which were contributed to by dry conditions. By November, continuing heat and lack of rain had desiccated the forests and agricultural land along the Great Dividing range in New South Wales and Queensland. Sydney received less than 2 millimeters of rain in December 2019, with temperatures reaching 40°C (104°F). Numerous intense bushfires occurred, some of which burnt Gondwanan rainforest remnants that had not experienced fires for millennia.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: Dry conditions in September 2019 contributed to several small to mid-range fires in north eastern New South Wales. By November of that year, continuing heat and lack of rain had desiccated the forests and agricultural land along the Great Dividing range in New South Wales and Queensland. Sydney received less than 2 millimeters (0.079 in) of rain in December 2019, with temperatures reaching 40°C (104°F). Numerous intense bushfires occurred, some of which burnt Gondwanan rainforest remnants that had not experienced fires for millennia.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Alice formed on December 30, 1954, from a trough of low pressure in the central Atlantic Ocean in an area of unusually favorable conditions. The storm moved southwestward and gradually strengthened to reach hurricane status. After passing through the Leeward Islands on January 2, 1955, Alice reached peak winds of 90 mph (140 km/h) before encountering cold air and turning to the southeast. It dissipated on January 6 over the southeastern Caribbean Sea.
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: December 30, 1954 (1954-12-30)... Dissipated: January 6, 1955 (1955-01-07)

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: No information was provided in the article about the total number of deaths associated with Hurricane Alice (December 1954).

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: There was an earlier hurricane named Alice in the season. Operationally, lack of definitive data prevented the U.S. Weather Bureau from declaring the system a hurricane until January 2. It received the name Alice in early 1955, though re-analysis of the data supported extending its track to the previous year, resulting in two tropical cyclones of the same name in one season. Subsequent to the confirmation of the existence of Hurricane Alice, the U.S. Weather Bureau Office in San Juan, Puerto Rico warned the islands of the northern Lesser Antilles to prepare for strong winds and rough seas. Hurricane Alice produced moderate to strong winds across the islands, peaking at 81 mph (130 km/h) in Saint Barthélemy and 75 mph (121 km/h) in Saba. The hurricane dropped moderate to heavy rainfall across several islands, including a peak of 11.27 inches (286 mm) in 48 hours recorded at Saba. Due to its small size, only a few islands received significant effects from the hurricane. Saint-Barthélemy, Saba, Anguilla, Sint Eustatius, and Saint Kitts reported damage from the hurricane, totaling $623,500 (1955 USD, $4.7 million 2006 USD). Damage was heaviest on Saba and Anguilla, occurring primarily to shipping facilities and crops.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Karen was a hurricane of non-tropical origin that formed in October of the 2001 Atlantic hurricane season. It developed out of the interaction between a cold front and an upper level trough on October 10 located to the south of Bermuda, and quickly strengthened as an extratropical storm. The storm passed near Bermuda on October 12, producing hurricane-force winds on the island. It then organized, becoming a subtropical cyclone on October 12 and a tropical cyclone on October 13. Karen strengthened to reach 80 mph (130 km/h) winds as a Category 1 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale, and after weakening over cooler waters, it made landfall on Nova Scotia as a tropical storm.
Time_with_Annotation: Hurricane Karen (2001) developed out of the interaction between a cold front and an upper level trough on October 10 located to the south of Bermuda, and quickly strengthened as an extratropical storm. The storm passed near Bermuda on October 12... It then organized, becoming a subtropical cyclone on October 12 and a tropical cyclone on October 13... Karen made landfall on southwestern Nova Scotia with winds of 45 mph (72 km/h) on October 15... After losing the remaining of its convection it became extratropical shortly after landfall.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: While passing to the south of Bermuda, the subtropical storm maintained winds of 70 mph (110 km/h), with wind gusts on the island surpassing 100 mph (160 km/h). After becoming dissociated from the Westerlies, the system turned northward, and began to develop convection over the center. In addition, the frontal characteristics of the subtropical storm continually weakened. On October 13, based on an Advanced Microwave Sounding Unit observation that stated that a warm core was present throughout the system, the National Hurricane Center designated the system as a tropical storm, and gave it the name Karen. At this point, Karen was located 200 miles (320 km) north of Bermuda.

Tropical Storm Karen produced light to moderate winds across Atlantic Canada, peaking at 47 mph (76 km/h) with a gust of 64 mph (103 km/h) in Cape George in Antigonish County, Nova Scotia, along with a 26 mph (42 km/h) report in Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: None

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage on Bermuda totaled to over $1.4 million (2001 USD; $1.7 2008 USD). In Atlantic Canada, Tropical Storm Karen produced light winds and rain, but caused minimal damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Storm Carmel was an extratropical cyclone that was part of the 2021-22 European windstorm season. It was named by the Hellenic National Meteorological Service on 16 December 2021 and is the first storm in the history of Israel to receive a name.
Time_with_Annotation: Storm Carmel was named by the Hellenic National Meteorological Service on 16 December 2021. Israel is expected to be impacted by winter storm Carmel.[2][2]

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Storm Carmel was an extratropical cyclone that was part of the 2021–22 European windstorm season. Storm Carmel was named by the Hellenic National Meteorological Service on 16 December 2021.
Cyprus suffered no significant damage in the storm.

Israel is expected to be impacted by winter storm Carmel.
At Ben Gurion Airport, more rain fell in two days than the monthly average. Mikveh Israel saw 175 millimeters (6.9 in) of rainfall over those two days (147 millimeters (5.8 in) in one day), the third highest recorded rainfall there in the past century.
In Israel, two homeless people died in the coastal city of Bat Yam and another in Tel Aviv, from hypothermia. Another death happened because of a car accident caused by torrential rains, bringing the death toll up to 4.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2015 Northern Chile floods were a series of mudflows that affected much of northern Chile, product of flash floods from different rivers due to unseasonal heavy rains in the area, causing severe damage in several towns of the Antofagasta, Atacama and Coquimbo regions.
Time_with_Annotation: The 2015 Northern Chile floods and mudflow affected much of northern Chile from 23 March 2015 to 25 March 2015, product of flash floods from different rivers due to unseasonal heavy rains in the area, causing severe damage in several towns of the Antofagasta, Atacama and Coquimbo regions.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The 2015 Northern Chile floods were a series of mudflows that affected much of northern Chile, product of flash floods from different rivers due to unseasonal heavy rains in the area, causing severe damage in several towns of the Antofagasta, Atacama and Coquimbo regions.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: 26 people died during the mudflow and 101 are officially missing, although it is expected that these numbers will increase as contact is reestablished with remote communities.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The government allocated 1.1 billion Chilean peso for the reconstruction.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The February 9--11, 2017 North American blizzard was a fast-moving but powerful blizzard that affected the Northeastern United States with winter weather in the time span of February 8--9. Forming as an Alberta clipper in the northern United States, the system initially produced light snowfall from the Midwest to the Ohio Valley as it tracked southeastwards. It eventually reached the East Coast of the United States and began to rapidly grow into a powerful nor'easter.
Time_with_Annotation: On February 6, an Alberta clipper developed near the Canada–United States border and dove southeastwards. By 09-12:00 UTC on February 9, the low had begun to move just offshore near the Delaware coastline. The storm system was absorbed by another system forming off the coast of Greenland on February 11.

Country_with_Annotation.United_States: The February 9–11, 2017 North American blizzard affected the Northeastern United States with winter weather in the time span of February 8–9. Up to 18 inches (46 cm) of snow as well as blizzard conditions were recorded in some of the hardest hit areas before the system moved away from the coastline early on February 10.
Country_with_Annotation.Canada: In Atlantic Canada, accumulations of snow were reported between 10 and 30 centimetres (4 and 12 in) on February 9 and 10th with the maximum axis along Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Western Newfoundland.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: One death was confirmed when a 59-year old doorman slipped and fell through a glass door in New York City on East 93rd Street, causing injuries to his face and neck. He was rushed to the hospital where he was pronounced dead.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: One death was confirmed when a 59-year old doorman slipped and fell through a glass door in New York City on East 93rd Street, causing injuries to his face and neck. He was rushed to the hospital where he was pronounced dead.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage: Unknown

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: On March 21, an area of low pressure moved ashore on the West Coast, with a limited amount of moisture available. As it moved eastward on March 22 it started to intensify and as such snowfall became widespread. The storm also began to transition into an extratropical cyclone, achieving a peak of 989 millibars (29.2 inHg) two times on March 23. Blizzard warnings were issued for areas around Denver due to the strong winds accompanying the system along with snowfall. Parts of Interstate 80 were shut down due to the extreme winter weather conditions. Denver International Airport was also shut down. Ahead of its cold front, thunderstorms began to fire up, prompting the National Weather Service to issue a tornado watch. A squall line later developed out of this as more storms began to fire up and move eastwards, with the severe weather threat shifting more to the east towards the East Coast. The system also brought ice accumulations from 0.25–0.75 inches (6.4–19.1 mm) from the Midwest into New England. It then rapidly weakened and moved offshore late on March 25, dissipating the next day.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The text does not provide specific information on the total economic damage or loss caused by the Late March 2016 North American blizzard.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Nestor was a large but short-lived and disorganized tropical storm which caused widespread tornadoes and heavy rain in the Southeastern United States during mid-October 2019. The sixteenth depression and fourteenth named storm of the erratic 2019 Atlantic hurricane season, Nestor originated from a broad area of low pressure over the Western Caribbean. It emerged in the Gulf of Mexico and began to organize slightly, becoming Potential Tropical Cyclone Sixteen due to its threat to the Southeastern United States. It gained a sufficient enough of a circulation to be designated Tropical Storm Nestor near the Florida Panhandle early on October 18, crawling to the northeast, and then finally transitioning into an extratropical cyclone due to strong shear from a nearby upper-level low before making landfall on the Florida Panhandle on October 19.
Time_with_Annotation: On October 18, the disturbance's circulation improved and became more defined, while the system was finally designated Tropical Storm Nestor.[7]. Nestor's post-tropical remnant was absorbed into another extratropical storm off the coast of the Southeastern United States on October 21.[11]

Country_with_Annotation.Honduras: The NHC began to monitor for a poorly defined area of low pressure that was forecast to form near Central America.
Country_with_Annotation.Central America: The low developed on October 11 and meandered almost parallel to the coast of Honduras for the next few days, before finally crossing over Central America near the Yucatan Peninsula on October 14.
Country_with_Annotation.Yucatan Peninsula: The low fully emerged into the Bay of Campeche on October 16 after bringing heavy rain to Central America and due to the warm temperatures in the Gulf of Mexico at the time, convection significantly improved with the system near the center and it was given a medium chance of development.
Country_with_Annotation.Southeastern United States: Potential Tropical Cyclone Sixteen due to its threat to the Southeastern United States.
Country_with_Annotation.Florida Panhandle: The disturbance's circulation, however remained elongated, and was still not named. Later that evening on October 18, the circulation improved and became more defined, while the system was finally designated Tropical Storm Nestor.
Country_with_Annotation.Southern Louisiana: Parts of Southern Louisiana and Alabama also received Tropical Storm Warnings, but were removed shortly after the storm's track shifted predominantly towards to the Florida Panhandle.
Country_with_Annotation.Alabama: Parts of Southern Louisiana and Alabama also received Tropical Storm Warnings, but were removed shortly after the storm's track shifted predominantly towards to the Florida Panhandle.
Country_with_Annotation.Northern Florida: Tornado watches were then issued shortly after the storm became post-tropical for much of Northern Florida and some parts of Georgia.
Country_with_Annotation.Georgia: Tornado watches were then issued shortly after the storm became post-tropical for much of Northern Florida and some parts of Georgia.
Country_with_Annotation.South Carolina: 3 indirect deaths occurred when heavy rains generated by Nestor's extratropical remnant caused a car crash in South Carolina.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: 3 indirect deaths occurred when heavy rains generated by Nestor's extratropical remnant caused a car crash in South Carolina.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage: $150 million (2019 USD)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Raja was a tropical cyclone that holds the 24-hour rainfall record of 674.9 mm (26.57 in) for the French Overseas Territory of Wallis and Futuna. The system was first noted by the Fiji Meteorological Service (FMS) as a weak tropical disturbance northeast of Tokelau in mid-December 1986. The system developed further as it moved southwest over the next few days, and it was classified as Tropical Cyclone Raja on 23 December.
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: 21 December 198

Country_with_Annotation.Tuvalu: Tropical Cyclone Raja caused extensive damage to crops, coastal installations and buildings and flooded low-lying areas on the island nation of Tuvalu.
Country_with_Annotation.Wallis and Futuna: Severe Tropical Cyclone Raja was responsible for one death as well as extensive damage to the islands' crops, coastal installations and buildings in Wallis and Futuna.
Country_with_Annotation.Tonga: Gale warnings were issued for the two islands and remained in place until 28 December, when the system had turned southwest and moved well away from the islands.
Country_with_Annotation.Fiji: Severe Tropical Cyclone Raja was responsible for FJ$16 million (US$14 million) in damage, one death and the worst flood of the Labasa River since 1929 in Fiji.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Paragraph: Severe Tropical Cyclone Raja was responsible for a single death as it impacted Fiji and parts of Polynesia, before its name was later retired from the South Pacific lists of tropical cyclone names.[6][2]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nabi (pronounced [na.bi]), known in the Philippines as Super Typhoon Jolina, was a powerful typhoon that struck southwestern Japan in September 2
Time_with_Annotation: On August 29, 2005, a tropical depression formed... Nabi dissipated soon afterward on September 12, 1

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Overall, Nabi killed 35 people.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Iwakunda, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Fukui Prefecture, Yamagata Prefecture, Ashoro, Teshikaga
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Ahead of the storm, high waves and gusty winds led to one drowning when a woman was knocked off a ferry in Takamatsu, Kagawa. Nabi caused a portion of the San'yō Expressway to collapse in Yamaguchi Prefecture, killing three people. In Fukui Prefecture, the winds knocked an elderly man off a bicycle, killing him. In Yamagata Prefecture, the winds damaged a window in a school, injuring several boys from the debris. One person was seriously injured in Kitakata, Fukushima after strong winds blew a worker from scaffolding of a building under construction. Effects from Nabi spread as far north as Hokkaido, where heavy rainfall damaged roads and caused hundreds of schools to close. In Ashoro, an overflown river flooded a hotel, and a minor power outage occurred in Teshikaga.
Throughout South Korea, the storm led to six fatalities and caused US$115.4 million in damages.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Irma, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Anding, was a powerful typhoon that struck the Philippines in November 1981. The twenty-fifth named storm and fourteenth typhoon of the 1981 Pacific typhoon season, Irma originated from an active monsoon trough to the east of the Philippines... Irma reached its peak wind speed of 205 km/h (125 mph)... After maintaining this intensity for 16 hours, Irma weakened considerably due to interaction with the mountainous terrain of the Philippines... In all, 595 were killed due to Irma.
Time_with_Annotation:
Formed: November 18, 1981
Dissipated: November 27, 1981
